‚∏∫ HIP-ARCHIVE-2 ‚∏∫ / hip-69-re-assertion-fee-reduction
Tracking/discussion issue: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/458 - HIP https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0069-reassertion-fee-reduction.md
edaatweets 07/26/2022 10:49 AM
# HIP 69: Re-assertion Fee Reduction - Author(s): @John Mac - Start Date: 2022-07-24 - Category: Economy - Original HIP PR: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/453 - Tracking Issue: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/458 - Status: In Discussion # Summary The average daily mining reward per hotspot is currently equal to around 50,000 DC; and it costs 1,000,000 DC to reassert a hotspot's location. As a result, it would take nearly a month for the average hotspot to earn enough to pay for one location reassertion. Therefore, if we are trying to expand the network and want hotspots in saturated areas to move into less saturated areas (or moreover in lone wolf-like areas), the current reassertion price is not viable and needs to be reduced. # Rendered View https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0069-reassertion-fee-reduction.md (edited)
HIP 69: Re-assertion Fee Reduction · Issue #458 · helium/HIP
HIP 69: Re-assertion Fee Reduction Author(s): @TheRealJohnMac50 Start Date: 2022-07-24 Category: Economy Original HIP PR: #453 Tracking Issue: This Status: In Discussion Summary The average daily m...

QQQ 07/27/2022 7:11 AM
Digerati 07/27/2022 9:55 AM
Great presentation, @John Mac - the one part I disagree with is something you mentioned toward the end, about forcing a GPS lock or otherwise to be able to assert - beyond people being able to bypass it, that would also be unworkable for hotspot hosting companies and individuals who onboard a hotspot to their wallet, then ship it to its ultimate destination
Digerati
Great presentation, @John Mac - the one part I disagree with is something you mentioned toward the end, about forcing a GPS lock or otherwise to be able to assert - beyond people being able to bypass it, that would also be unworkable for hotspot hosting companies and individuals who onboard a hotspot to their wallet, then ship it to its ultimate destination
John Mac 07/27/2022 9:56 AM
Very valid point. scratches that idea off the list
3
Digerati 07/27/2022 9:58 AM
But otherwise, yeah, great ideas! I like the simplicity and likely much easier implementation of cutting the assertion fee in half, but it may be better to put in a bit more work like others had brought up, doing a time-based decay since last assertion, maybe discounting the second assertion to specifically address the issue you brought up that you faced (and many others I would guess, if it's the first time they're onboarding a hotspot)
1
Digerati
But otherwise, yeah, great ideas! I like the simplicity and likely much easier implementation of cutting the assertion fee in half, but it may be better to put in a bit more work like others had brought up, doing a time-based decay since last assertion, maybe discounting the second assertion to specifically address the issue you brought up that you faced (and many others I would guess, if it's the first time they're onboarding a hotspot)
John Mac 07/27/2022 10:06 AM
I'm completely onboard with concepts like time-based decay and second assertion discounts. However, with all of the recent ongoing developments, it would certainly be extremely efficient to simply cut the reassertion fee in half. Would love to hear how the dev team feels about this as well. (edited)
1
1
John Mac
I'm completely onboard with concepts like time-based decay and second assertion discounts. However, with all of the recent ongoing developments, it would certainly be extremely efficient to simply cut the reassertion fee in half. Would love to hear how the dev team feels about this as well. (edited)
Digerati 07/27/2022 10:13 AM
If it's just a reduction of the location assertion fee, that's changing one chain variable, could be done with basically zero effort
10:13
https://hp.hn/cv/#staking_fee_txn_assert_location_v1
10:13
Not sure how much effort the other more involved ideas would take
Digerati
If it's just a reduction of the location assertion fee, that's changing one chain variable, could be done with basically zero effort
John Mac 07/27/2022 10:21 AM
Precisely, I think it makes more sense on various levels to keep the original proposal of reducing the reassertion fee in half. Time-based decay would cause people to delay reasserting their hotspots for the fee reduction, retroactively delaying the expansion of the network.
1
Digerati
Great presentation, @John Mac - the one part I disagree with is something you mentioned toward the end, about forcing a GPS lock or otherwise to be able to assert - beyond people being able to bypass it, that would also be unworkable for hotspot hosting companies and individuals who onboard a hotspot to their wallet, then ship it to its ultimate destination

John Mac 07/27/2022 11:52 AM
Yup, that is exactly why I submitted this proposal. The high outdated fee prevents people from moving their hotspots to less saturated areas and expand the network.

groot 07/28/2022 6:35 AM
Remember that you need to be able to resync the chain at any point and in order to do that it must be deterministic. A constantly changing DC amount also means apps etc should change their transaction on the fly and constantly. I think keeping it deterministic on some set constant is preferable.
groot
Remember that you need to be able to resync the chain at any point and in order to do that it must be deterministic. A constantly changing DC amount also means apps etc should change their transaction on the fly and constantly. I think keeping it deterministic on some set constant is preferable.
John Mac 07/28/2022 6:36 AM
Always appreciate your valuable input Groot. In that case, what would be your formula recommendation?
groot 07/28/2022 6:38 AM
I thought you already defined it as 50% of what it was now, I have no opinion on the staking fee either way. I would favor an approach that would achieve your goals with as little as implementation as possible but that is my personal opinion.
groot
I thought you already defined it as 50% of what it was now, I have no opinion on the staking fee either way. I would favor an approach that would achieve your goals with as little as implementation as possible but that is my personal opinion.
John Mac 07/28/2022 6:38 AM
That was ny original thought, and why I simply chose halving the fee. Maybe 5 minutes of scripting to make it happen.
06:40
Change <1000000 DC> to <500000 DC> (or whatever it actually would be to that end)
groot 07/28/2022 6:40 AM

John Mac 07/28/2022 6:40 AM

06:42
Although @koditech idea is logically sound and agreeable, as well as other's ideas (such as time based reduction, second assertion reduction, exc.) it is simply most efficient to keep the reduction amount as I originally proposed to reduce the reassertion fee in half.
John Mac

John Mac 07/28/2022 6:48 AM

06:48

John Mac 07/28/2022 6:51 AM

06:54
Since my proposal, we've heard many fantastic ideas, but the original proposal of halving the reassertion fee remains the most technically efficient and easiest implementation method. If there are no objections, I'd like to request that we take this HIP to vote.
Siegfried 07/28/2022 7:09 AM
Is there a convincing reason why a reassertion fee might be considered "too low"? Meaning: are there possible behaviors that "we" want to disincentivize by having a reassertion fee being higher than x, whatever x may reasonably be? If not, I'd go for a much lower reassertion fee. Just reminded myself in time to reading the full HIP So: In the HIP draft, there is mention that lower fees help location spoofers. Can someone explain in detail why this may be the case? Would that be the only reason for not having very low reassert fees?
Siegfried
Is there a convincing reason why a reassertion fee might be considered "too low"? Meaning: are there possible behaviors that "we" want to disincentivize by having a reassertion fee being higher than x, whatever x may reasonably be? If not, I'd go for a much lower reassertion fee. Just reminded myself in time to reading the full HIP So: In the HIP draft, there is mention that lower fees help location spoofers. Can someone explain in detail why this may be the case? Would that be the only reason for not having very low reassert fees?
John Mac 07/28/2022 7:13 AM
To reiterate, the concept of lowering reassertion fees may help location spoofers, just as it will help legitimate hotspots operators actually move their hotspots into less saturated areas. This is why (after much back-and-forth thought,) I chose the reduction amount to be 500,000 DC. This way, it's half the original fee, while still being high enough to prevent abuse.
Siegfried 07/28/2022 7:14 AM
How do lower reassert fees make spoofing easier? (edited)
John Mac
To reiterate, the concept of lowering reassertion fees may help location spoofers, just as it will help legitimate hotspots operators actually move their hotspots into less saturated areas. This is why (after much back-and-forth thought,) I chose the reduction amount to be 500,000 DC. This way, it's half the original fee, while still being high enough to prevent abuse.
John Mac 07/28/2022 7:15 AM
With the current average daily earnings being around 50,000 DC, the reduction amount to 500,000 DC would still take the average hotspot to pay around 10 days worth of mining earnings.
Siegfried
How do lower reassert fees make spoofing easier? (edited)
John Mac 07/28/2022 7:16 AM
The lower the fee, the less cost to spoof your location. Same in reverse, the lower the fee, the less burden for legitimate hotspots operators to move their hotspots into less saturated areas. As well as, lesson the burden on people purchasing second hand hotspots, and for "fat fingers" human errors. (edited)
Digerati 07/28/2022 7:27 AM
@John Mac it wouldn't be hard at all to base something on the oracle price, as that's on chain: https://docs.helium.com/blockchain/oracles/
1
07:27
Average hotspot earnings, which is probably ultimately what you'd want, would be a bit harder to get, but not much - Explorer already shows it on the Statistics page of each hotspot (for 7D+ views)
07:28
But any non-zero amount of dev and testing work would likely delay implementation of this HIP a good amount
07:29
Easiest would be just cutting the location assert chain var in half, and that would also let us get data on things like how many asserts there are pre/post change and provide more (or less) incentive to pass future HIPs changing that further

John Mac 07/28/2022 7:41 AM
Hip 67 went to vote almost immediately, but sure, happy to wait a week. The reason why I feel it should go to vote now, is since we've already heard various brilliant alternatives. All of which lead to the same conclusion, that the proposed reduction amount is the most technically efficient method. Therefore, IMO it wouldn't make sense to go another week of possibly hearing additional alternatives, that will also likely lead to the same conclusion. Regardless, if you say we wait a week, then that's what will be.

John Mac

Fizzy 07/28/2022 8:35 AM
here is my 2cents. While reducing it outright, one value, is the easiest, is it the best way to handle what you are trying to solve? No. What you are trying to solve is the accidental "I assigned here but didn't mean to because opps", "I live in NYC and need to gtfo" and the from the HIP, overall encourage people to move to less dense areas. Right? But this "simple" change benefits everyone, and not just the fraction of the people that would fall under the intended groups of hotspots, this includes gamers. So this could lead to undesired economical change. Some examples: - Gamers could now have the ability to change locations more frequently, which could have the benefit of eluding the people that watch for such activity, or even putting up a defense that the hotspot has been transferred to someone else so remove it from denylist. Also mind that location changes clear out witness data on explorer (maybe the anti cheat sites would still have old data, idk). - With this change, technically the price of a hotspot should be reduced by all manufactures by that amount to, because they pay for the first one and thus has always been built into the price. Now, this is so negligible of a change, but I am just saying that they will be more than happy to save that 950,000 DC and not pass those savings to customers. It'll add up over time. - Benefits Emritt and other hosting, this is just reduces the cost overhead of them swapping hosts. Though honestly this would not change operations for them, just like above it'll benefit them and nothing else changes. - Once the value is reduced, it will be hard to increase it again outright, due to the negativity of raising the cost rate of anything. Overall this should not be rushed at all. Overall this needs to be a slightly more complex system to target the demographic that you intend to help, while everyone else that doesn't need that benefit be excluded. Examples have already been mentioned, such as having to do with time (based on blocks) or transmit scale.
Fizzy
here is my 2cents. While reducing it outright, one value, is the easiest, is it the best way to handle what you are trying to solve? No. What you are trying to solve is the accidental "I assigned here but didn't mean to because opps", "I live in NYC and need to gtfo" and the from the HIP, overall encourage people to move to less dense areas. Right? But this "simple" change benefits everyone, and not just the fraction of the people that would fall under the intended groups of hotspots, this includes gamers. So this could lead to undesired economical change. Some examples: - Gamers could now have the ability to change locations more frequently, which could have the benefit of eluding the people that watch for such activity, or even putting up a defense that the hotspot has been transferred to someone else so remove it from denylist. Also mind that location changes clear out witness data on explorer (maybe the anti cheat sites would still have old data, idk). - With this change, technically the price of a hotspot should be reduced by all manufactures by that amount to, because they pay for the first one and thus has always been built into the price. Now, this is so negligible of a change, but I am just saying that they will be more than happy to save that 950,000 DC and not pass those savings to customers. It'll add up over time. - Benefits Emritt and other hosting, this is just reduces the cost overhead of them swapping hosts. Though honestly this would not change operations for them, just like above it'll benefit them and nothing else changes. - Once the value is reduced, it will be hard to increase it again outright, due to the negativity of raising the cost rate of anything. Overall this should not be rushed at all. Overall this needs to be a slightly more complex system to target the demographic that you intend to help, while everyone else that doesn't need that benefit be excluded. Examples have already been mentioned, such as having to do with time (based on blocks) or transmit scale.
John Mac 07/28/2022 8:49 AM
First of all, I appreciate your input. Second, you appear to have many misconceptions as to the intend and "intended groups of hotspots." To explain in detail: - This HIP does not pertain to makers whatsoever. Meaning, that this HIP does not change the onboarding or first assertion fee. Merely the reassertion fees. - This HIP is not intended to target any specific group of hotspots. Its meant to help everyone who is looking to reassert their hotspots to less saturated areas. (As well as, those that are purchasing their hotspots second hand, and those that made "fat finger" human errors.) - To reiterate, this HIP was created due to the very outdated amount of the reassertion fees. Which, at current daily earnings average, would cost the average hotspot nearly a month's worth of mining. (edited)
2
John Mac
First of all, I appreciate your input. Second, you appear to have many misconceptions as to the intend and "intended groups of hotspots." To explain in detail: - This HIP does not pertain to makers whatsoever. Meaning, that this HIP does not change the onboarding or first assertion fee. Merely the reassertion fees. - This HIP is not intended to target any specific group of hotspots. Its meant to help everyone who is looking to reassert their hotspots to less saturated areas. (As well as, those that are purchasing their hotspots second hand, and those that made "fat finger" human errors.) - To reiterate, this HIP was created due to the very outdated amount of the reassertion fees. Which, at current daily earnings average, would cost the average hotspot nearly a month's worth of mining. (edited)
Fizzy 07/28/2022 9:04 AM
- Understood - That's confusing, because you just stated a targeted a specific group; "reassert their hotspots to less saturated areas". Taking this intended outcome, there should only be a reduced fee if you are moving to a transmit scale higher than your current one. One could still benefit from moving into a more dense area (though illogical it is). - Then one could argue that the HNT staking 10,000 is outdated. Which if a HIP were to be made, you would have a bunch of people for and then a good amount that are not for it, and then a whole lot of people debating the set value; why? Because of economical changes that would happen. Now this pales in comparison, I know, because at the end of the day, we are talking about the price going from getting a fast food meal, to a fast food value meal.
09:07
In the HIP you also mention that it is only once per year. Why was that set? I mean clearly you understand that there should be a protector against abuse, so why not focus that even more. And sorry if this get personal, but most HIPs tend to be, are you caught in one of these situations? Where you personally need to move your hotspots and find it difficult with the reward rate now?
Fizzy
- Understood - That's confusing, because you just stated a targeted a specific group; "reassert their hotspots to less saturated areas". Taking this intended outcome, there should only be a reduced fee if you are moving to a transmit scale higher than your current one. One could still benefit from moving into a more dense area (though illogical it is). - Then one could argue that the HNT staking 10,000 is outdated. Which if a HIP were to be made, you would have a bunch of people for and then a good amount that are not for it, and then a whole lot of people debating the set value; why? Because of economical changes that would happen. Now this pales in comparison, I know, because at the end of the day, we are talking about the price going from getting a fast food meal, to a fast food value meal.
John Mac 07/28/2022 9:08 AM
- There is no intended specific group, that was merely an example of who would benefit positively for both themselves and the network. - TS scale is not a factor in this HIP. It doesn't matter whether the TS scale increases or decreases after reassertion. What matters is that the reassertion fee is outdated and too costly.

John Mac 07/28/2022 9:11 AM
Costly to the average hotspots. The average hotspot earns around 50,000 DC daily, and the reassertion fee is 1,000,000 DC. That means the average hotspot need to pay nearly a month's worth of mining for a reassertion.
3
09:12
I was worried that many wouldn't understand this, since their daily average may be many times greater than the Network‚Äôs daily average (of 50,000 DC per hotspot). (edited)
09:16
Remember, those that are in extremely over saturated areas earn much less than the network daily earnings average of 50,000 DC per hotspot. Those are the ones that are hurting from the current outdated high reassertion fee the most. (edited)
1
John Mac 07/28/2022 9:25 AM
The reduction would lesson the burden and will help many move to less saturated areas, whom otherwise would not have moved their hotspots. Imagine you are in a hotspot with 40+ other hotspots. You did your absolute best to optimize your setup, by purchasing LMR 400 low loss cables, proper 3dbi (or whatever dbi antenna), pole, lightning arrestor, and everything else necessary to get your hotspot on your roof and in the most optimal position with clear LOS. Yet, you're only earning 10,000 DC per month, due to mamy others moving into your hex over time resulting in your TS scale (and moreover in the TS scales of those around you) to less than 0.1, and there's nothing you can do about it- other than moving your hotspot to a different city/less saturated area. However, since it would cost you nearly a year's (10 months) worth of mining, you won't do it. This HIP would lesson the burden by half.
2

John Mac 07/28/2022 9:30 AM
I mentioned once per year, to prevent location spoofing, and to prevent other forms of abuse. Such as spoofing locations until you find the best spoofed location earner, changing your hotspots location over nearby hex to increase your TS scale (that would've been decreased due to other moving into your hex for example, exc. No, I'm not in any of these situations that you mentioned. However, it would of course help enable me to move some of my hotspots in dense areas, to a specific urban area that has no hotspots for over 30 miles in all directions.

09:55
Feels like you are under that impression, which couldn't be more false. Irrefutable Facts: - It costs 1,000,000 DC for hotspots operators to reassert their locations. - At the time that the reassertion fee was created/determined, the average hotspot earned several times more than what the average hotspot earns today. - The average hotspot currently has a daily earnings average of 50,000 DC. - The 1,000,000 DC reassertion fee costs the average hotspot operators nearly a month's worth of their earnings. - Reducing the reassertion fee will likely result in hotspots moving to less saturated areas, which will expand the network. (edited)

21:58

John Mac 07/29/2022 6:50 AM
@groot I've been thinking about what you said regarding a majority of reassertions being done with the goal of increasing TS. Although all of my hotspots have had a 1.0 TS scale since day one, I imagine that to be accurate. Additionally, I've been having doubts about how many people would actually move their hotspots into less saturated areas (as a direct result of my proposed reassertion fee reduction), and I'm beginning to doubt whether it would actually do more good than harm. Originally, I proposed that the reassertion fee reduction be limited to once per hotspot per year, in order to prevent reassertion abuse. Is this technically possible? If not, I/we must must come up with a technically viable solution to prevent reassertion abuse (as a result of the fee reduction) please.

John Mac 07/29/2022 4:07 PM
I was eager to go to vote at first, but Keenan was right that she would wait, lots of new ideas have stemmed since and we may implement some of them. (edited)
16:07
Right now, I'm needing a core dev to advise on the possibility of excluding the reassertion fee reduction, for those inserting into a hex with 3 or more hotspots. (@619OTA's idea.) Additionally, waiting on a core dev to confirm that it would be an acceptable amount of technical work to implement a minimum 10km distance (from the original location) requirement for the reassertion fee reduction (@groot's idea.) Finally, I'm also waiting for a core dev to confirm that it would be a reasonable amount of technical work to implement my original proposed method to prevent abuse/spoofing, which is by limiting the reassertion fee reduction to once per hotspot per year. (edited)
16:11
The aforementioned suggestions would certainly help to prevent abuse of the reassertion fee reduction. (edited)
Siegfried 07/29/2022 10:01 PM
Tbh, I am really surprised by how much of a weight is put on that 'fee reduction makes spoofing more attractive' argument. Maybe I still don't understand that spoofing issue well enough - but isn't the fee only influencing how financially attractive spoofing is and not how easy it is from the technical side? Is Helium really that bad at identifying spoofing that a reassert fee reduction has such a big impact? (edited)
22:03
One might almost think, PoC is quite useless. (edited)
hashc0de 07/29/2022 10:59 PM
Purely commenting on the technical scope questions here.
Right now, I'm needing a core dev to advise on the possibility of excluding the reassertion fee reduction, for those inserting into a hex with 3 or more hotspots. (@619OTA's idea.)
This is pretty straightforward to do, imo. The way I'd think about it is to have two variables. One for reduction amount and another to define the "3 or more". I'd say to harmonize with HIP 15's density_tgt_res var (which is set to 4 today) for the latter so it's matching some of the intentions of the network today.
Additionally, waiting on a core dev to confirm that it would be an acceptable amount of technical work to implement a minimum 10km distance (from the original location) requirement for the reassertion fee reduction (@groot's idea.)
Also seems fine. You'd have to change how the staking fee is calculated based on the prior and proposed location. Seems pretty simple. Neither of these changes would cause a significant computational overhead increase to the chain (on both validity checks and for absorbing into the ledger).
1
22:59
All that being said, I think there are some economic, UX, and resourcing questions that come to mind. On the economic side, I have opinions but would like someone else to chime in on the impact to reducing HNT burn here. Maybe relevant and someone can pull up some revenue numbers for discussion. On the UX side, this is not just a core blockchain upgrade as scoped above. The unscoped bits are the work in various maker apps, making sure all Hotspots can use a variable rate depending on the inputs, etc. And if a maker decides not to respect the reduction amount, the chain may happily accept the higher fee amount (typically fees are implemented minimums for simplicity). As far as resourcing, who will build it? I think this HIP with the new scope proposed here requires some code.
23:02
As far as the argument about fee reduction vis-à-vis making it easier to arbitrage, it's just a fact. Make something cheaper and you'll have more of it. One of the reasons for having fees at all on chain is to increase friction somewhat to make it costly to do too much of it and DoS storage or computational resources of the chain.
hashc0de
All that being said, I think there are some economic, UX, and resourcing questions that come to mind. On the economic side, I have opinions but would like someone else to chime in on the impact to reducing HNT burn here. Maybe relevant and someone can pull up some revenue numbers for discussion. On the UX side, this is not just a core blockchain upgrade as scoped above. The unscoped bits are the work in various maker apps, making sure all Hotspots can use a variable rate depending on the inputs, etc. And if a maker decides not to respect the reduction amount, the chain may happily accept the higher fee amount (typically fees are implemented minimums for simplicity). As far as resourcing, who will build it? I think this HIP with the new scope proposed here requires some code.

John Mac 07/30/2022 5:22 AM
We've discussed this here, and the general consensus was that the burn wouldn't have a significant impact at all, since we are taking about REassertion fee reductions (not all assertions). Additionally, if you confirm technically viable, the reduction would be limited to once per hotspot per year, in addition to other two limiting conditions that you already confirmed technically viable. Thus, the actual reassertion fee reduction burn would not have a significant economic impact, and the limitations in place will prevent spoofing/gaming of any kind (as a direct result of the reassertion fee reduction). (edited)
John Mac 07/30/2022 6:35 AM

I literally considered every single suggestion (mine included) to be based on what would be a reasonably acceptable amount of technical work for the core dev team. My entire original proposal was based on the core dev team doing the work as well, which is why I kept it soo technically simple to begin with. I'd write the code personally if I could and I know of no one else capable (other than you/the core dev team.)

waveform 07/30/2022 10:51 AM
Here's an ETL report I saw the other day https://etl.dewi.org/question/158-data-credits-burned-per-day-in-usd If you click the table view (middle bottom) you get get the table of DC burns Looking at 29th assert_location/1000000dc = 1557 location asserts add_gateway/40000000dc = 97 hotspots added taking an assumption that averaged over a long period of time every hotspot add is matched by an assert (its less but not by anything that matters in this case) So 1557-97 = 1460 reasserts yesterday The unknown in that is how many of those are onboarded over a year ago, and would get the 50% off coupon. Another ETL enquiry to write....
2

"1 year" is about 525k blocks

waveform
Here's an ETL report I saw the other day https://etl.dewi.org/question/158-data-credits-burned-per-day-in-usd If you click the table view (middle bottom) you get get the table of DC burns Looking at 29th assert_location/1000000dc = 1557 location asserts add_gateway/40000000dc = 97 hotspots added taking an assumption that averaged over a long period of time every hotspot add is matched by an assert (its less but not by anything that matters in this case) So 1557-97 = 1460 reasserts yesterday The unknown in that is how many of those are onboarded over a year ago, and would get the 50% off coupon. Another ETL enquiry to write....
hashc0de 07/30/2022 3:25 PM
Last 4 weeks of DC burn for "subsequent" location asserts. nonce > 2 is a safe assumption that these are all re-assertions: ~12.3m DC in 4 weeks so roughly 160.5M DC a year SQL you can use in the ETL: with min_block as (select height from blocks where timestamp >= now() - interval '4 weeks' limit 1) select sum((t.fields->>'staking_fee')::numeric) from min_block, transactions t where t.type = 'assert_location_v2' and t.block >= min_block.height and (t.fields->>'nonce')::numeric > 2 and (t.fields->>'staking_fee')::numeric > 0
hashc0de
Last 4 weeks of DC burn for "subsequent" location asserts. nonce > 2 is a safe assumption that these are all re-assertions: ~12.3m DC in 4 weeks so roughly 160.5M DC a year SQL you can use in the ETL: with min_block as (select height from blocks where timestamp >= now() - interval '4 weeks' limit 1) select sum((t.fields->>'staking_fee')::numeric) from min_block, transactions t where t.type = 'assert_location_v2' and t.block >= min_block.height and (t.fields->>'nonce')::numeric > 2 and (t.fields->>'staking_fee')::numeric > 0

groot 07/31/2022 12:06 PM
Assert locations are sort of expensive (computation wise) so you don't want them too cheap either (in my opinion)
groot
Assert locations are sort of expensive (computation wise) so you don't want them too cheap either (in my opinion)
John Mac 07/31/2022 12:08 PM
Why I chose to reducing to 500,000 DC and not 5,000DC (for example).
12:11
Irrefutable Facts (and my opinion on the last one): - It costs 1,000,000 DC for hotspots operators to reassert their locations. - The average hotspot currently has a daily earnings average of 40,000 DC. - Since inception, the average hotspot earned several times more than what the average hotspot earns today. - The 1,000,000 DC reassertion fee costs the average hotspot operators nearly a month's worth of their earnings. - Given the aforementioned reasoning, the current reassertion fee amount is outdated, and unfair to the average hotspot. (edited)
groot 07/31/2022 12:12 PM
Yes on 1, doubt on 2, fine on 3, fine on 4, opinion on 5
groot
Yes on 1, doubt on 2, fine on 3, fine on 4, opinion on 5
John Mac 07/31/2022 12:13 PM
You doubt that the average hotspot earned several times more than what the average hotspot eanrs today at the time that the reassertion fee amount was determined?
John Mac
You doubt that the average hotspot earned several times more than what the average hotspot eanrs today at the time that the reassertion fee amount was determined?
groot 07/31/2022 12:13 PM
Just as a reminder, the assertion fee is in DC, hotspots probably earned a lot more HNT at that time but that says nothing about the DC per day.
groot
Just as a reminder, the assertion fee is in DC, hotspots probably earned a lot more HNT at that time but that says nothing about the DC per day.

12:18

John Mac 07/31/2022 1:03 PM
What would the percentage equation be?
13:08
The reasons why I haven't gone down that percentage road, is due to the specifics, technical work, and the fact that we can always cross that bridge when we get to it. As of the today, the bridge which we arrived at, is that the average hotspot would need to pay around a month's worth of earnings for a reassertion, and this HIP is merely addressing that fact. Additionally, to ease the burden on new people joining, and human errors. (edited)
John Mac 07/31/2022 1:16 PM
Side note, even with this reassertion fee reduction, it would still cost the average hotspot nearly two weeks of earnings for a reassertion. Arguably, still too high. However, (in addition to the other three previously mentioned methods,) it will serve to prevent gaming as a direct result of the reassertion fee reduction. (edited)

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 07/31/2022 1:53 PM
At current avg and orcale, that is 495600 DC
14:00
It would be dynamic. If the daily average hnt per hotspot were to drop by let's say, 50%, the resassert fee would also drop 50%. It's based on 7.5 days of avg earnings to pay for a reassert (edited)
14:01
Same if the Oracle dropped 50%
John Mac 07/31/2022 2:01 PM
So that I may understand, where'd you get (7.5 / 0.00001) from?
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 07/31/2022 2:02 PM
7.5 is days. 0.00001 is the convertion to get it into DC
14:02
Simplified it would be (avg daily hnt * Oracle price) * 750,000dc = Reassert fee in DC
John Mac 07/31/2022 2:03 PM
That doesn't add up, since the current reassertion fee reduction should amount to around 12 days worth of mining, not 7.5 days. (edited)
John Mac
That doesn't add up, since the current reassertion fee reduction should amount to around 12 days worth of mining, not 7.5 days. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 07/31/2022 2:04 PM
.07 hnt daily average and Ocrable of 9.44 at time of making the equation. Plug it in
14:05
You have to convert since DC is pegged to the dollar.
14:07
I started with your 50% reduction in the fee and worked backwards so that currently it would be about 500,000dc and then dynamically change going forward
John Mac 07/31/2022 2:08 PM
"(avg daily hnt * Oracle price) * (7.5 / .00001) = Reassert fee in DC" (0.04 X 9.42) = 0.3768 (7.5 / .00001) = 750,000 0.3768 X 750,000 = 282,600
John Mac

groot 07/31/2022 2:22 PM
You can't base a staking_fee validation on something in the etl.
groot
You can't base a staking_fee validation on something in the etl.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 07/31/2022 2:22 PM
Why?
14:23
https://etl.dewi.org/question/402-average-rewards-per-day?numDays=7
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Why?
groot 07/31/2022 2:23 PM
The chain must be deterministic and resyncable.
groot
The chain must be deterministic and resyncable.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 07/31/2022 2:23 PM
In english please?
1
groot 07/31/2022 2:24 PM
A validator must be able to determine whether that transaction is valid or not, and thus you can only use information that a validator has available. What the ETL has available is more than a validator has because a validator has limited history and the validator needs performance.
groot
A validator must be able to determine whether that transaction is valid or not, and thus you can only use information that a validator has available. What the ETL has available is more than a validator has because a validator has limited history and the validator needs performance.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 07/31/2022 2:24 PM
ah gotcha

waveform 07/31/2022 4:27 PM
Throwing some spanners into the equation discussion BTW You can get "monthly target emissions" with the chain var "monthly_reward"/1000000000000 as its measured in bones Review your equation on 31st July/1st Aug 2023 at the next halving. Do you need "8" as another new chain var to change in Aug? Consider what happens now and then with oracle prices of $1 or $100 (outlying numbers) ? Also what happens with 500K and 2M (outlying numbers) hotspots in a years time on halving day and day before. Ive also seen comments around that DC/HNT ratio could be subject to a HIP to increase price DC so consider specifying fee in $ rather than DC if you are aiming at a specific $ price. then convert to DC on the fly - this would make it variable DC (I believe there is a chain var for DC/HNT but cant identify it)

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 07/31/2022 6:21 PM
Ive also seen comments around that DC/HNT ratio could be subject to a HIP to increase price DC so consider specifying fee in $ rather than DC if you are aiming at a specific $ price.
There was no target $ amount, but instead was based on a 50% of currently levels and then going forward it would adjust dynamically, to be basically "average user's rewards = enough to reassert" no matter the oracle price, hnt emissions, etc. Unless I'm missing something, everything you mentioned is already taken into account.
18:23
Review your equation on 31st July/1st Aug 2023 at the next halving. Do you need "8" as another new chain var to change in Aug?
Nope. When HNT emissions halves, so would the reassert fee.

John Mac 08/02/2022 5:12 AM
@groot @ElonTusk | 5Gchipped When you get a chance, please confirm the final accurate dynamic equation.
Toad 08/02/2022 6:53 AM
% of average monthly earnings of all hotspots= assertion fee ?
Toad
% of average monthly earnings of all hotspots= assertion fee ?
John Mac 08/02/2022 7:50 AM
That is basically how it is now, this HIP aims to reduce that, based on the following math. {([Monthly targeted emissions / active hotspots] / 30) * Oracle price} * (8 / 0.00001) = Reassert fee in DC In layman's terms, this math dynamically ensures that the reassert fee is (relative to the current reassert fee amount) more fair for whatever the current average hotspot earns. (edited)
John Mac
@groot @ElonTusk | 5Gchipped When you get a chance, please confirm the final accurate dynamic equation.

waveform 08/06/2022 1:15 AM
Percent split is right. But use the same numbers apart from a jump to Active of 800K and $20 as the Oracle price (not too crazy numbers). And the assert cost is now 19 cents more than current cost.
01:19
Looks like you need to Squareroot one of the numbers you are using to get a less linear number progression
waveform 08/06/2022 1:47 AM
Think of what changes, how often, direction and percentage of change % of HNT to Miners/DAOs , changes once a year, goes up, very small change Monthly HNT reward, changes every two years, down, 50% changes Active hotspots, changes per block, should go up, small percent. But problems in validators could reduce online by 50% during short term halts and it should be say 20-40% higher than it is now with offchain PoC DC to $ price, does not change, needs a HIP - would likely cost 50-100% more if it did. HIP would need to consider this HIP Oracle price, changes all the time, can go any direction can change by factors not percentage (edited)
waveform
Looks like you need to Squareroot one of the numbers you are using to get a less linear number progression
John Mac 08/06/2022 7:20 AM
Can you please clarify this further?
waveform
Think of what changes, how often, direction and percentage of change % of HNT to Miners/DAOs , changes once a year, goes up, very small change Monthly HNT reward, changes every two years, down, 50% changes Active hotspots, changes per block, should go up, small percent. But problems in validators could reduce online by 50% during short term halts and it should be say 20-40% higher than it is now with offchain PoC DC to $ price, does not change, needs a HIP - would likely cost 50-100% more if it did. HIP would need to consider this HIP Oracle price, changes all the time, can go any direction can change by factors not percentage (edited)
John Mac 08/06/2022 7:26 AM
Not understanding various things you stated. Regarding oracle price, amount of active hotspots, monthly rewards, that is all already factored into the equation. Regarding off chain poc, why should it be 20%-40% higher? Regarding DC to $ price, the core reason why the equation works dynamically, is because that doesn't change.
07:27
In other words, everything else that changes is factored in percentages, the one constant is the DC to $ value. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
(((("monthly_reward"/100000000 * 0.6115) / Active Hotspots) / 30 Days) * Oracle Price) * (8 / 0.00001) = Reassert Fee In DC
John Mac 08/06/2022 7:29 AM
Going to mess around with this in a bit after breakfast
1
John Mac
Not understanding various things you stated. Regarding oracle price, amount of active hotspots, monthly rewards, that is all already factored into the equation. Regarding off chain poc, why should it be 20%-40% higher? Regarding DC to $ price, the core reason why the equation works dynamically, is because that doesn't change.

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 08/06/2022 2:03 PM
Just to be clear again, this equation isn't supposed to output one price. It's to make the cost of a reassert equal the average rewards over 8 days.
14:05
So yes, the swings can be big. That's fine. I don't see the need for a square root.

Any HIP that has a equation and/or If/Then statement in it can always be implemented quicker than one that doesn't.

shadowfax 08/07/2022 6:14 AM
Maybe: currentDC = (((("monthly_reward"/100000000 * 0.6115) / Active Hotspots) / 30 Days) * Oracle Price) * (8 / 0.00001) if (blocks-since-last-reassert > 365 days) then currentDC = percent-reduction-for-1-year * currentDC If (currentDC > $9 USD) then currentDC = $9 --- A minimum reduction of $1 If (currentDC < $4 USD) then currentDC = $4 --- A maximum reduction of $6

John Mac 08/07/2022 9:53 AM
Was going to submit my final draft on Friday, delayed due to waiting to perfect the aforementioned equation. Initial tests (of the original equation) resulted in me finding an issue, that Elon resolved by adding the 0.6115 factorial, which is the amount of the monthly_rewards distributed to hotspots. If I have no objections/additions/changes by the end of today (for me that's in approximately 11 hours from now), then I'm going to run a bunch more test examples on the aforementioned equation. If it adds up as intended, I'll submit my final draft for vote. As of now, I intend on following Neil's advice to implement the immediate halving, the dynamic equation, and the min/max amount of the reassertion fee. In addition to, the three gaming prevention methods that we previously discussed and agreed upon. (edited)
John Mac
Was going to submit my final draft on Friday, delayed due to waiting to perfect the aforementioned equation. Initial tests (of the original equation) resulted in me finding an issue, that Elon resolved by adding the 0.6115 factorial, which is the amount of the monthly_rewards distributed to hotspots. If I have no objections/additions/changes by the end of today (for me that's in approximately 11 hours from now), then I'm going to run a bunch more test examples on the aforementioned equation. If it adds up as intended, I'll submit my final draft for vote. As of now, I intend on following Neil's advice to implement the immediate halving, the dynamic equation, and the min/max amount of the reassertion fee. In addition to, the three gaming prevention methods that we previously discussed and agreed upon. (edited)

waveform 08/07/2022 10:19 AM
If you are thinking of retaining a variable (with max) fee then you can add a bit of logic after the equation that goes IF "Reassert Fee In DC" > 1,000,000 then "Reassert Fee In DC" = 1,000,000 If you do go with a variable fee then also think about how does the hotspot owner find out this variable fee before they do a location assert? Is it calculated and shown before they confirm assert? If so then this is a function of the Vendor App, so all owners of Vendor apps need to be in your stakeholder list

John Mac 08/08/2022 5:56 AM
@Keenan I want to sincerely thank you for ensuring that we gave the community proper time to voice their opinions and implement them. As a direct result of your decision, this HIP has evolved from a relatively primitive approach, to a dynamic level success. Thank you for your advice, thoughts, opinions, and ensuring that the community had ample time to voice their opinions, and allow this HIP to evolve into what it is now. Thank you very much. Now that it has been weeks, we've heard the communitys thoughts/opinions, implemented them, and I've submitted the above final draft changes, to include the dynamic equation and mathematical logic, in addition to the 3 gaming prevention methods, on behalf of the community I ask that this HIP be allowed to go to vote please. If for any reason you feel that we should still delay the vote, we will of course respect your decision. Thank you for your consideration.

waveform
"< 3" = less than 3, and "> 3" = greater than 3 - as far as I remember from programming
groot 08/08/2022 7:22 AM
Indeed < 3 is either 0, 1 or 2 while > 3 is everything else from 4 and up (assuming positive integers and 0) (edited)
waveform
"< 3" = less than 3, and "> 3" = greater than 3 - as far as I remember from programming
John Mac 08/08/2022 7:22 AM
So there's no mathematical/programming difference between '<3' and '< 3' (edited)
07:23
But I'll correct it now regardless
John Mac
So there's no mathematical/programming difference between '<3' and '< 3' (edited)

Good morning everyone, Following up, here it is, the final HIP 69 Reassertion Fee Reduction draft. If anyone has any objections, additions, subtractions, or otherwise, please speak up. https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0069-reassertion-fee-reduction.md
waveform 08/09/2022 5:02 AM
So if this HIP passes, the only time a 1,000,000 DC would apply to the hotspot owner would be for the 2nd and subsequent asserts if the distance is less than 10KM between the asserts?
waveform
So if this HIP passes, the only time a 1,000,000 DC would apply to the hotspot owner would be for the 2nd and subsequent asserts if the distance is less than 10KM between the asserts?
John Mac 08/09/2022 5:10 AM
To clarify in summary: - This HIP only applies to REassertions. Not the first (vendor paid $10 location) assertion fee. - This HIP only applies to those who are REasserting their hotspots to a distance equal to or greater than 10km (away from the original location point that is being changed). - This HIP only applies to REassertions, equal to or greater than 10km away from the original location, and only to those who are reasserting their hotspots into Res8 hexes with less than 3 hotspots [equal to or less than 2 hotspots]. - The reassertion fee reduction will be limited to once per hotspot per year. Meaning, after a given hotspot's first reassertion fee reduction, said hotspot would need to wait 525k blocks (approximately one year) in order to be eligible for its second reassertion fee reduction. All other location assertions, that do not meet the aforementioned requirements, will not have their assertions fee reduced. (edited)
1
05:16
The core goals of this HIP is to reduce the burden on those moving their hotspots into less saturated areas, as well as new people joining the network who purchased second hand hotspots that need to reassert their locations, NOT to give everyone an assertion fee discount. Hence, the aforementioned gaming prevention requirements. (edited)
waveform pinned a message to this channel. 08/09/2022 5:18 AM
John Mac 08/09/2022 5:42 AM
Initiated pull request, to add the pinned message 'in summary' clarification. https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/463
John Mac
Initiated pull request, to add the pinned message 'in summary' clarification. https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/463
waveform 08/09/2022 11:15 AM
As Blockchain time is measured in Blocks, it would be more accurate to say 525K blocks (approximately 1 year). Even validator unstaking period is measured in blocks. And that approx is assuming 60s blocktimes, currently 525K blocks takes over 13 months. Fingers crossed with offchain PoC it wont

John Mac 08/10/2022 10:14 AM
Please read the pinned messages, if you're trying to reassert your location with the goal of increasing your TS, (unless you're still meeting the 3 requirements) your reassertion fee will not be reduced. This HIP will not give everyone a reassertion fee discount, and is designed to only assist those that are reasserting due to moving their hotspots to less saturated areas or those purchasing second hand hotspots.
John Mac
Please read the pinned messages, if you're trying to reassert your location with the goal of increasing your TS, (unless you're still meeting the 3 requirements) your reassertion fee will not be reduced. This HIP will not give everyone a reassertion fee discount, and is designed to only assist those that are reasserting due to moving their hotspots to less saturated areas or those purchasing second hand hotspots.

John Mac 08/22/2022 7:17 AM

John Mac 08/22/2022 7:31 AM
No excuses, I do apologize for not making the time for the last few non-technical/non-fundamental changes yet. However, they are not cause to prevent this HIP from going to vote, as explained. This HIP started off as a simple 'cut the reassertion fee in half', with the only gaming prevention method being once per hotspot per year, and (with everyone's help) has evolved into a timeless dynamic level equation, with 3 advanced gaming prevention methods that will certainly prevent a vast majority of would-be gaming as a result the reassertion fee reduction. Thank you all for your advice, contributions, and feedback.

FYI I'm at work but decided to get this done now. Before I get into it, thank you for your suggestions, much appreciated. Drawbacks. Need to identify the 3 gaming prevention methods. So could be a problem. I've resolved this by adjusting the definitive verbiage. Unresolved Questions: More detail would help. Yes, due to the specific three gaming prevention methods, success may be quite easily measured simply by people being issued the Reassertion fee reduction. I've adjusted the Success Metrics section to say just that. Just trying to get the factorial breakdown together...
John Mac 08/22/2022 3:58 PM
(((("monthly_reward"/100000000 * 0.6115) / Active Hotspots) / 30 Days) * Oracle Price) * (8 / 0.00001) = Reassert Fee In DC.
Siegfried 08/22/2022 3:58 PM
So instead "0.6115" there should be "(dc_percent+poc_challengees_percent+poc_witnesses_percent)"
John Mac
(((("monthly_reward"/100000000 * 0.6115) / Active Hotspots) / 30 Days) * Oracle Price) * (8 / 0.00001) = Reassert Fee In DC.
Siegfried 08/22/2022 4:02 PM

16:03
Because the halvings schedule schedules changes of them, too.
16:06
Like this: (((("monthly_reward"/100000000 * (dc_percent+poc_challengees_percent+poc_witnesses_percent)) / Active Hotspots) / 30 Days) * Oracle Price) * (8 / 0.00001) = Reassert Fee In DC. (edited)

16:18

16:20
I also liked the notation we used in school where we put the units in brackets. Like: ReassertFee[DC]=(AverageDailyRewardsTargetToHotspots[HNT/day]/Active Hotspots) x OraclePrice[USD/HNT] x 8 [day] x 100.000 [DC/USD] (edited)
16:21

16:40

John Mac

Siegfried 08/22/2022 4:43 PM

Siegfried

John Mac 08/22/2022 4:43 PM

16:45
In other words, "(1)HNT= (x)$"?
Siegfried 08/22/2022 4:45 PM
Look at your formula: first you calculate an amount of HNT (average daily amount of HNT per active hotspot), multiplying with the oracle price gives you a USD value of that, then you transform that in DC by multiplying with 100.000 DC / USD (the DC price) (edited)
John Mac
In other words, "(1)HNT= (x)$"?
Siegfried 08/22/2022 4:45 PM
Now I don't understand this.
John Mac
In other words, "(1)HNT= (x)$"?
John Mac 08/22/2022 4:45 PM
x = oracle price.
Siegfried 08/22/2022 4:48 PM
At the moment, the oracle price is, say, 6.5 USD per HNT, so if we have, say, 0.1 HNT average daily reward, then the USD value if the average daily reward is 0.1 HNT * 6,5 USD/HNT = 0.65 USD.
16:50
Then you transform this into the amount of DCs this is worth, by dividing by 0.00001 USD/DC or written more easily by multiplying with 100.000 DC/USD. Now the USD measurement unit cancels out, and you have 65.000 DC (edited)
John Mac 08/22/2022 4:51 PM
Ok, so we were saying the same thing this entire time is what you are saying.
John Mac
Ok, so we were saying the same thing this entire time is what you are saying.
Siegfried 08/22/2022 4:52 PM
Yup
1
Siegfried
Yup

John Mac 08/22/2022 5:03 PM

Siegfried 08/22/2022 5:06 PM
Just a draft of what may be inserted at the beginning of the stage 2 section. Only a possible element, not fully fledged (also: not a native English speaker here): "In stage two, the reassertion fee will be dynamically set to what an average hotspot would earn in 8 days. These earnings change depending on the monthly rewards target set by the HIP 20 halvings schedule, the number of active hotspots and the price of HNT. This notwithstanding, the reassertion fee shall never be higher than 500.000 DC (= 5 USD) and never lower than 100.000 DC (=1 USD)." (edited)
Siegfried
Just a draft of what may be inserted at the beginning of the stage 2 section. Only a possible element, not fully fledged (also: not a native English speaker here): "In stage two, the reassertion fee will be dynamically set to what an average hotspot would earn in 8 days. These earnings change depending on the monthly rewards target set by the HIP 20 halvings schedule, the number of active hotspots and the price of HNT. This notwithstanding, the reassertion fee shall never be higher than 500.000 DC (= 5 USD) and never lower than 100.000 DC (=1 USD)." (edited)

This notwithstanding, the reassertion fee shall never be higher than 500.000 DC (= 5 USD) and never lower than 100.000 DC (=1 USD)." (edited)
John Mac 08/22/2022 6:45 PM
I'm much more inclined to keep the formula as is, with the only change being to define the 0.6115, as you suggested. Additionally, including that explanation of the formula, with some small tweaks that I'll send/make (when I get a chance). (edited)
John Mac
FYI I'm at work but decided to get this done now. Before I get into it, thank you for your suggestions, much appreciated. Drawbacks. Need to identify the 3 gaming prevention methods. Numbered bullet points is a suggestion I've more clearly defined the gaming prevention methods. https://github.com/TheRealJohnMac50/HIP/commit/174ee2a2d0b10d7737d3d93d7cb1c7729c62c157 Rationale: Not evidence based, has no references. So could be a problem. I've resolved this by adjusting the definitive verbiage. Unresolved Questions: More detail would help. Refer to hashc0des comments I've added a lot more detail, as per Hashc0des comments. Success Metrics: Any suggestion on how these metrics could be measured? Yes, due to the specific three gaming prevention methods, success may be quite easily measured simply by people being issued the Reassertion fee reduction. I've adjusted the Success Metrics section to say just that. Pull request submitted: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/468 To view commit/changes: https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1001546633554710650/1011425418236133447 (edited)
waveform 08/23/2022 5:14 AM
It seems you misunderstood my comment about success criteria Say a problem is that children are drowning in rivers/lakes and the solution is to get them to learn to swim. And building a swimming pool where they can take lessons is the way to do it. Then the success criteria is not that a pool was built or that children are taking lessons. Its that less children are drowning than before. Eg 10 died last year and 5 died this year even though the number of children wild swimming increased. That is the success criteria. So the success criteria for this HIP is not that the assert fee is reduced but this "Therefore, if we are trying to expand the network and want hotspots in saturated areas to move into less saturated areas (or moreover in lone wolf like areas)" is measurably successful. So what is it that changes to be measured if people are not doing something and this hip will make them do it? Something like .... hotspot assertions to locations more than 10km away into Res8 hexes of < 3 increases, and the number of reasserts increases And if you are doing it in 2 stages (stage 1 is easy as its just a var change), why not have this as a measurable test that can be evaluated to see if the stage 2 programming effort is actually worthwhile.

Its that less children are drowning than before. Eg 10 died last year and 5 died this year even though the number of children wild swimming increased. That is the success criteria. John Mac 08/23/2022 5:39 AM

John Mac 08/23/2022 5:46 AM

Siegfried
Like this: (((("monthly_reward"/100000000 * (dc_percent+poc_challengees_percent+poc_witnesses_percent)) / Active Hotspots) / 30 Days) * Oracle Price) * (8 / 0.00001) = Reassert Fee In DC. (edited)

John Mac 08/23/2022 9:05 AM

John Mac 08/27/2022 1:15 PM
Good afternoon, Figured I'd take some of my time off to make the aforementioned changes. Here is the final equation in stage 2 of this HIP: (((("monthly_reward"/100000000 * (dc_percent + poc_challengees_percent + poc_witnesses_percent)) / Active Hotspots) / 30 Days) * Oracle Price) * (8 / 0.00001) = Reassert Fee In DC. As Siegfried explained in layman's terms, for easier comprehension: (Average Daily Rewards Per Hotspots [HNT/day]) x OraclePrice[USD/HNT] x 8 [Days] x 100.000 [DC/USD] = Reassert Fee In DC. I'll be submitting the git pull momentarily.
John Mac 08/27/2022 1:23 PM

John Mac
Waveform, I made the changes that we discussed as well. Additionally, I specified that, 'Stage 2 will only be implemented if we see hotspots moving to a distance of 10km or greater, within Res8 hexes that contain less than 3 hotspots (post stage 1).'

(edited)
Siegfried 08/27/2022 4:30 PM
I don't have the mental capacity to backread the whole discussion, but I'd propose to keep things simple. Also sharing a few rough thoughts: 1. It is very likely very hard to measure the success of this hip, as the amount of the relocation fee is just one of many causal factors that have an influence on the decision of people whether to relocate a hotspot or not, and if, where to. If you really want to isolate the effect of the relocation fee amount, you'd probably need a controlled experiment, cutting the population of helium hotspots randomly in subgroups, each assigning different relocation fees. I guess nobody would want that. 2. There are very likely already some hotspot relocations happening from time to time at current fees that meet the proposed criteria for reduced re-assert fees. Taking only one (or a very small number) of hotspot moves that meet your criteria is totally flawed because you cannot tell, if a reduced fee caused these moves or not. 3. If anything, I'd compare (ratio of hotspot relocations that meet your criteria:all other hotspot relocations) over x weeks before fee reduction with the ratio y weeks after fee reduction. Has this ratio gone up? This might indicate that a fee reduction for these kinds of location changes may have an impact, but you very likely still can't be sure depending on how small or big the ratio change is. (edited)
Siegfried 08/27/2022 4:48 PM
4. If we assume that stage 1 has an impact (which I guess it does), we shouldn't try to be perfect at the cost of discussing this for another few weeks. Given that it is a non-trivial data analysis problem to correctly assess the impact, I could very well live with stage 2 being implemented without a proper success evaluation of stage 1. Being able to easily communicate: (a) 'we want to make it easier to reallocate a hotspot to where more coverage is needed' and (b) we need a minimum fee, but above that, relocations to areas in which coverage is still needed, shouldn't come with re-assert costs that take an average hotspot more than roughly 8 days to earn back' is sufficient reason for me to implement that. (edited)
Siegfried
I don't have the mental capacity to backread the whole discussion, but I'd propose to keep things simple. Also sharing a few rough thoughts: 1. It is very likely very hard to measure the success of this hip, as the amount of the relocation fee is just one of many causal factors that have an influence on the decision of people whether to relocate a hotspot or not, and if, where to. If you really want to isolate the effect of the relocation fee amount, you'd probably need a controlled experiment, cutting the population of helium hotspots randomly in subgroups, each assigning different relocation fees. I guess nobody would want that. 2. There are very likely already some hotspot relocations happening from time to time at current fees that meet the proposed criteria for reduced re-assert fees. Taking only one (or a very small number) of hotspot moves that meet your criteria is totally flawed because you cannot tell, if a reduced fee caused these moves or not. 3. If anything, I'd compare (ratio of hotspot relocations that meet your criteria:all other hotspot relocations) over x weeks before fee reduction with the ratio y weeks after fee reduction. Has this ratio gone up? This might indicate that a fee reduction for these kinds of location changes may have an impact, but you very likely still can't be sure depending on how small or big the ratio change is. (edited)
John Mac 08/28/2022 6:39 AM
1. A "controlled experiment" is the only way to properly determine a hypothesis. However, it is not possible, as I believe you already mentioned. Nobody would be ok with some people being charged more/less than others. 2. Agreed, as I mentioned, I'm open to advice on what specific amounts or percentages should be considered a success. 3. Yes, Waveform mentioned this, and it really is the only method of gaging success. However, it still remains unknown what amount/percentage of hotspots meeting the criteria would be considered a success of stage 1. 4. Of course, stage 1 will have an impact. The questions are, will it help cause hotspots to reassert their locations and meet the criteria, and will it have a positive or negative economic impact? 4(a). This was communicated in the HIP mutliple times. For example, 'In order to ease the burden on hotspots moving to less saturated areas...' 4(b). This is why I added the if/then analysis logic. 'IF "Reassert Fee In DC" < 100,000 DC THEN "Reassert Fee In DC" = 100,000 DC' 'IF "Reassert Fee In DC" > 500,000 DC THEN "Reassert Fee In DC" = 500,000 DC' Simply put, the reassertion fee [for those meeting the criteria] can never be less than 100,000 DC ($1), nor greater than 500,000 DC ($5). I'm certainly in agreement with you that it shouldn't take more than 8 days worth of mining for those reasserting their hotspots to less saturated areas. Appreciate your input and advice. Thank you (edited)
Keenan
personally id get a bit more discussion for a week or so before going for a vote
John Mac 08/28/2022 2:06 PM
Hi, following up here. It has been a month that we gave to hear everyone's opinions, and acted upon their opinions/suggestions. This HIP started off as a simple 'cut the reassertion fee in half', with the only gaming prevention method being once per hotspot per year, and (with everyone's help) has evolved into a timeless dynamic level equation, with 3 advanced gaming prevention methods that will certainly prevent a vast majority of would-be gaming as a result the reassertion fee reduction. If there are no objections, please advise when this HIP may go to vote.
John Mac 08/29/2022 6:20 AM

John Mac
Good afternoon, Figured I'd take some of my time off to make the aforementioned changes. Here is the final equation in stage 2 of this HIP: (((("monthly_reward"/100000000 * (dc_percent + poc_challengees_percent + poc_witnesses_percent)) / Active Hotspots) / 30 Days) * Oracle Price) * (8 / 0.00001) = Reassert Fee In DC. As Siegfried explained in layman's terms, for easier comprehension: (Average Daily Rewards Per Hotspots [HNT/day]) x OraclePrice[USD/HNT] x 8 [Days] x 100.000 [DC/USD] = Reassert Fee In DC. I'll be submitting the git pull momentarily.

waveform 09/01/2022 6:26 AM
My understanding of the feedback from Hashc0de and Sc0tt was that there are 3 parts to this HIP (a) A fixed reduction (b) A variable reduction and (c) an Anti gaming restriction. And (a) could be done now as stage 1 but without (c) as both (b) and (c) require new coding and testing and could require additional coding from vendor apps. Would you want to do stage 1 just as a fixed reduction and no antigaming rule?
waveform

And (a) could be done now as stage 1 but without (c) as both (b) and (c) require new coding and testing and could require additional coding from vendor apps. Would you want to do stage 1 just as a fixed reduction and no antigaming rule?
John Mac 09/01/2022 6:27 AM

waveform
My understanding of the feedback from Hashc0de and Sc0tt was that there are 3 parts to this HIP (a) A fixed reduction (b) A variable reduction and (c) an Anti gaming restriction. And (a) could be done now as stage 1 but without (c) as both (b) and (c) require new coding and testing and could require additional coding from vendor apps. Would you want to do stage 1 just as a fixed reduction and no antigaming rule?
John Mac 09/01/2022 6:28 AM
Without the antigaming rules, people wanting to increase their TS scale and location spoofers will certainly take advantage. (edited)
06:34
If the (a) and (c) will not be implemented, then my preference would be to disregard this HIP completely.
06:41
The core reasons why I wrote this HIP, is with the intention of helping people expand the network, and easing the burden on new people joining the network. Not help harm the network, which IMO, would certainly be the result without the antigaming rules.
hashc0de 09/01/2022 6:59 AM

06:59

John Mac 09/01/2022 7:35 AM

07:38
I'm assuming that it would be voted in, even without the antigaming rules, because who doesn't want a "fee discount." However, had I known that was ever going to be a possibility, I would not have written this HIP. Please either also implement the antigaming rules, or wait until the competition of HIP 70.
07:39

John Mac

waveform 09/02/2022 1:51 AM
Well it was "Later" for me (UK time) so I thought I've better write this when not tired after a long day.
2
01:55
Both the Variable Assert Fee and the Anti-Gaming rule will need dev work on the blockchain, dev work on the vendor app core code, and implementation of this code by the vendor apps (include the Helium Hotspot App as a Vendor app)
01:57
The Assert task on the vendor app can only propose a fee and a location. And get accepted or refused. It cant currently enquire or validate a request for a variable amount or a ruled location.
02:00
So this would involve the blockchain devs, the app devs and the devs for the vendor apps to put this in place.
waveform 09/02/2022 2:09 AM
Its also been commented that the HIP needs more data analysis content for the anti gaming section and the success metrics need to quantify how hotspots are asserting now vs how it can be seen this HIP was successful. Analysis help can be requested.
02:13
A proposal is a Temperature Check Vote with options being (a) Implement stage 2 after work on HIP 70 related work (some blockchain work is needed to be done if HIP 70 passes or doesnt) and do some analysis and improve metrics before a final vote or (b) dont proceed with HIP 69
02:19
I realise this does not meet the probable urgency in the assert fee change that was the original intent in this vote. But that could be done with a simple HIP to reduce the accepted fee to a fixed xxx,xxx DC which is a simple blockchain variable change to accept that lower fee. The vendor apps still need to propose this lower fee though. As I understand it they could still propose the higher fee and it would get accepted.
groot 09/02/2022 5:31 AM
The first part, simply lowering the assertion fee, seems rather straight forward. Deciding whether to go through with the rest based on metrics would require determining the distribution of distance of the reasserts, if the move is to a lower TS and similar. When this is known from before the change you can see whether the change has had the desired effect by comparing to after the change. Distance is probably a relatively easy to determine metric, the only hindrance there is that the amount of data is unwieldy. TS will be a little more difficult as you will have to determine the TS of other hotspots in or near the hex you are moving to.
groot

Deciding whether to go through with the rest based on metrics would require determining the distribution of distance of the reasserts, if the move is to a lower TS and similar. When this is known from before the change you can see whether the change has had the desired effect by comparing to after the change. Distance is probably a relatively easy to determine metric, the only hindrance there is that the amount of data is unwieldy. TS will be a little more difficult as you will have to determine the TS of other hotspots in or near the hex you are moving to.

waveform 09/02/2022 10:05 AM
An example - a report dump is created on how many hotspots are reasserted a month for last few month that are <10km and now many >10km, and then how many of those two are in hexes with less than 3 or 3+. Does >10km and ‚ù§Ô∏è in hex number quantity show a downward trend? It could show an upward trend because thats what gaming clusters moving around more often might look like. If it shows a downward trend then describe what would be a positive trend over a specfic monitoring period. Eg downward trend is average 6% a month, success metric is this downward trend is halted and week on week reasserts over 2 months are increasing.

John Mac 09/02/2022 11:55 AM
I'm not entirely in agreement with your definition of trends and success of this HIP. The goals of this HIP are not to increase network revenue, but to ease the burden on those expanding the network and joining the network. Therefore, success of this HIP may not be determined based on the amount of total assertions or pertaining trend. As long as we see more hotspots [meeting the criteria] reasserting their hotspots after stage 1 is implemented, then there were those [meeting the criteria] before the implementation of stage 1, then that would determine the success of this HIP. (edited)

But there are mainly two things, no measurement or success criteria and that there is an easy part and and difficult part to implement so split the parts for speed. John Mac 09/05/2022 6:46 AM
There is no phase/stage without the antigaming rules. Since without the antigaming rules, there most certainly will be abuse by people wanting to increase their TS scale and of course by location spoofers. Suggesting that there be two stages, as they are intended to be now. Stage 1 is the fixed rate (500,000 DC) and the antigaming rules. Stage 2 is the variable rate and the antigaming rules. Either stage's success may be measured when we see more hotspots [meeting the antigaming rules criteria] reasserting their hotspots. What is not viable, is the current REassertion fee amount of 1,000,000 DC. The metrics that make it more viable, is either/both the reduced fixed rate, and/or the reduced variable rate. Happy to make any necessary changes. However, all of the aforementioned is exactly how this HIP is already written. Previously, I was suggesting the possibility of splitting the vote into 3, to separate the antigaming from the two rates. However, that was merely for voting purposes, and really shouldn't be an option (without the antigaming rules) IMO. (edited)
06:51
Since the [source/script] code necessary for the antigaming rules doesn't exist yet and I'm incapable of providing it, perhaps it may be best to delay this HIP completely until post HIP 70? (edited)
John Mac
There is no phase/stage without the antigaming rules. Since without the antigaming rules, there most certainly will be abuse by people wanting to increase their TS scale and of course by location spoofers. Suggesting that there be two stages, as they are intended to be now. Stage 1 is the fixed rate (500,000 DC) and the antigaming rules. Stage 2 is the variable rate and the antigaming rules. Either stage's success may be measured when we see more hotspots [meeting the antigaming rules criteria] reasserting their hotspots. What is not viable, is the current REassertion fee amount of 1,000,000 DC. The metrics that make it more viable, is either/both the reduced fixed rate, and/or the reduced variable rate. Happy to make any necessary changes. However, all of the aforementioned is exactly how this HIP is already written. Previously, I was suggesting the possibility of splitting the vote into 3, to separate the antigaming from the two rates. However, that was merely for voting purposes, and really shouldn't be an option (without the antigaming rules) IMO. (edited)

John Mac 09/05/2022 7:12 AM
Personally, I'd rather this HIP be redacted completely, than any reduction implemented without the antigaming rules- since IMO without the antigaming rules, there will certainly be people taking advantage of reduced reassertion fees. However, from what I've been hearing, it seems that there may be those that believe it is time to reduce the reassertion fee (without the antigaming rules), regardless of whether or not there will be abuse. Which is why I am suggesting that we have a 3 part vote, to determine if that is the case or not. If that is where we are going, then I'd need to specify that stage 1 is merely a reduced fixed rate without antigaming, and stage 2 is the variable rate with the antigaming rules.
John Mac
Personally, I'd rather this HIP be redacted completely, than any reduction implemented without the antigaming rules- since IMO without the antigaming rules, there will certainly be people taking advantage of reduced reassertion fees. However, from what I've been hearing, it seems that there may be those that believe it is time to reduce the reassertion fee (without the antigaming rules), regardless of whether or not there will be abuse. Which is why I am suggesting that we have a 3 part vote, to determine if that is the case or not. If that is where we are going, then I'd need to specify that stage 1 is merely a reduced fixed rate without antigaming, and stage 2 is the variable rate with the antigaming rules.

07:21

John Mac

John Mac 09/05/2022 7:36 AM
However, what if we see 1000 assertions not made for the intentions of this HIP, and only 100 made with the intention of this HIP? The 1000 unintended assertions may be seen as reason not to implement stage 2, but out of the 1000, the antigaming rules may have prevented 950 of them. In that case, would we consider that in reality 100 were asserted as intended and only 50 were not?

groot 09/06/2022 12:06 PM
So this will get you roughly (over the last 150k blocks): check_min_distance 34269 check_max_hex_density 165157 check_all 28910 total 215259 dtype: int64
12:06
Few of those reasserts actually meet the criteria it seems
cokes 09/06/2022 12:17 PM
@John Mac reading through your HIP on this point:
This HIP only applies to REassertions. Not the first assertion/onboarding. To clarify, the original/first location assertion price will not be changed, merely the reassertion prices (from the 2nd assertion and on.)
the assert/reassert chain variable is the same. there will need to be a new chain variable introduced if you want the first assert to stay $10 and subsequent reasserts to be $5.
groot
So this will get you roughly (over the last 150k blocks): check_min_distance 34269 check_max_hex_density 165157 check_all 28910 total 215259 dtype: int64
John Mac 09/06/2022 12:20 PM
First and foremost, this data is extremely helpful, thank you Groot. Out of 215259 assertions, only 28910 (or around 13%) met the antigaming criteria. Perhaps, now we may consider the success metrics to be, if 14% or more of all location assertions meet the antigaming rules criteria. (edited)
cokes
@John Mac reading through your HIP on this point:
This HIP only applies to REassertions. Not the first assertion/onboarding. To clarify, the original/first location assertion price will not be changed, merely the reassertion prices (from the 2nd assertion and on.)
the assert/reassert chain variable is the same. there will need to be a new chain variable introduced if you want the first assert to stay $10 and subsequent reasserts to be $5.

John Mac 09/09/2022 6:38 AM
@groot I feel like the last outstanding item is determining what proper success metrics of stage 1 should be and I cannot possibly determine it without you. Thank you for your help, contributions, advice, and assistance. Just a note, even if we were to say that 20% of reassertion meeting the criteria is necessary to be considered successful, then that would mean stage 2 may only apply to 20% of reassertions. However, in reality, it will be way less, due to the once per hotspot per 525k blocks (approximately once per year) antigaming rule. That being said, please help me determine the success metrics percentage. I'm of the opinion that if we are currently at around 13%, then somewhere between 15% - 20% should be considered success. What are yours (and everyone's) thoughts on this? (edited)
groot 09/09/2022 11:09 AM
The graphs show that in the recent block history the value is more towards 15% meeting the criteria already, so I would go with something like 20% or even 25%. In the end it is your choice, so definitely not binding advice (edited)
groot
The graphs show that in the recent block history the value is more towards 15% meeting the criteria already, so I would go with something like 20% or even 25%. In the end it is your choice, so definitely not binding advice (edited)
John Mac 09/09/2022 11:26 AM
In all honesty, there's no logical way for me to determine whether any percentage makes more sense than another (percentage amount). Being purely technical (mathematically), even a 1% increase does indicate success. Additionally, I wouldn't want stage 2 or this entire hip disregarded over a couple percent difference, between whatever amount we determine and the actual results. For example, say we chose 25%, and the actual result is 23%. IMO it would be unreasonable to disregard stage 2 over 2%, when 23% would be nearly double the amount prior to the completion of stage 1. This is precisely why I intentionally didn't specify a percentage amount in my success metrics. Perhaps, I should merely indicate that success will be measured when we see hotspots reasserting and meeting the criteria, but ultimately the team and/or foundation will decide whether or not stage 1 was successful. (edited)
John Mac 09/09/2022 4:29 PM
Don't know if the team/foundation is ok with it, was merely a suggestion, but whomever would be writing the code are the ones that should have a right to decide if it's worth their time and effort IMO. (edited)
16:33
Wonder how Hashc0de and the other devs feel (regarding what should determine the success of stage 1). (edited)

In all honesty, there's no logical way for me to determine whether any percentage makes more sense than another (percentage amount).
