For example, say we chose 25%, and the actual result is 23%. IMO it would be unreasonable to disregard stage 2 over 2%, when 23% would be nearly double the amount prior to the completion of stage 1. John Mac 09/13/2022 7:40 AM
Maybe we should at least have one antigaming rule in stage 1? IMO it's important to limit the reassertion fee reduction to once per hotspot per 525k blocks (approximately once per year) to prevent abuse from people looking to increase their TS scale and location spoofers. Regarding your price question, I've covered this with my if/then analysis. IF "reassert fee in DC" > 500,000 DC ($5) THEN "Reassert Fee In DC" = 500,000 DC ($5) IF "Reassert Fee In DC" < 100,000 DC THEN "Reassert Fee In DC" = 100,000 DC ($1) Thus, the if/then analysis supercedes the mathematical equation. As a result, if stage 2 is implemented, the reassertion fee reduction [for those meeting all antigaming rules criteria] will never be greater than $5, nor less than $1.
07:44
https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0069-reassertion-fee-reduction.md

If there is a trend then being better than the trend is a measurable improvement, which is all I think is needed. Im not the one deciding. And if that is a temperature vote then after...... John Mac
Hmm.. should we just close this hip and be done with it then? Should we ask all makers if their apps would work ok here (and if so how)? (edited)
waveform 09/16/2022 5:01 AM
Ive mentioned this before. To have 2 options for a fee would need the vendor app to enquire or calculate a new fee and/or use a new chain var. So all vendors apps would have to implement it, the app team at Nova would have to write this change for the vendor apps to implement - if they decided to implement.
waveform 09/16/2022 5:14 AM
This HIP is one of those things that sounds so simple but when we look at how its to work there are so many changes needed in so many parts of the process. The only simple implementation is to half price the Assert/Reassert fee from $10 to $5, which could be permanent or could be revoked on a increase of the value of HNT to say more than x$ for y days. Anything else needs new chain vars, some rules based calculation in the blockchain or the vendor app and changes in the way the vendor app and the blockchain handshake a reassert pass or fail. (edited)
waveform
Ive mentioned this before. To have 2 options for a fee would need the vendor app to enquire or calculate a new fee and/or use a new chain var. So all vendors apps would have to implement it, the app team at Nova would have to write this change for the vendor apps to implement - if they decided to implement.

groot 09/16/2022 5:20 AM
Yes this can be done with a simple chain var if you also lower the first assertion price (the one paid by the maker). If you want two assertion fees one for the first time (paid by maker) and one for reassertions you need more code.

John Mac 09/16/2022 5:21 AM

groot 09/16/2022 5:21 AM

John Mac
Can this be done just with a simple chain var or must the vendors implement in their apps as well? If the vendors must implement as well, then where does that leave this hip? Should I be contacting all vendors? If yes, how?
waveform 09/16/2022 5:23 AM
Whats been said above is that an assert and a reassert are the same instruction from an app. Its just lat+long and a fee and a payer. If the payer does not have the fee then it fails, if all ok it passes. So the process would change and that process is instigated by the app. So Nova would have to write some more code for the vendors to implement.
groot
that being lower them both or wanting more code?
John Mac 09/16/2022 5:23 AM
My utmost priority since day one is to make the technical work as easy as possible
groot
Yes this can be done with a simple chain var if you also lower the first assertion price (the one paid by the maker). If you want two assertion fees one for the first time (paid by maker) and one for reassertions you need more code.

John Mac

John Mac 09/23/2022 11:31 AM
Before I implement this into the HIP, can you please just explain to me why you're ok with stage 1 being simply to cut all location assertion fees in half, without any antigaming rules or otherwise? In my mind, it is guaranteed to help those looking to increase their TS scales, and location spoofers. Don't get me wrong, I understand that there is much more technical work needed to implement anything else, and I understand that it may be necessary to implement stage 1 without any antigaming rules. However, I can't shake the feeling of wondering whether it will do more harm than good to the network (without any antigaming rules). As much as I want this HIP to be implemented quickly, I'm finding it difficult to implement stage 1 with no antigaming rules. The core goals of this HIP is to help those people who want to expand the network, and new people joining the network. Without the antigaming rules, I'm genuinely concerned that it may end up helping more people that are up to nothing good for the network, than those that this HIP intends to help. (edited)
John Mac
Before I implement this into the HIP, can you please just explain to me why you're ok with stage 1 being simply to cut all location assertion fees in half, without any antigaming rules or otherwise? In my mind, it is guaranteed to help those looking to increase their TS scales, and location spoofers. Don't get me wrong, I understand that there is much more technical work needed to implement anything else, and I understand that it may be necessary to implement stage 1 without any antigaming rules. However, I can't shake the feeling of wondering whether it will do more harm than good to the network (without any antigaming rules). As much as I want this HIP to be implemented quickly, I'm finding it difficult to implement stage 1 with no antigaming rules. The core goals of this HIP is to help those people who want to expand the network, and new people joining the network. Without the antigaming rules, I'm genuinely concerned that it may end up helping more people that are up to nothing good for the network, than those that this HIP intends to help. (edited)

Overboosted (It's not YOUR hex) 11/20/2022 2:16 PM
Because of makers letting their accounts run low, I am onboarding and asserting any new hotspots I purchase while they still have enough DC. I am asserting them in areas that are remote and have no other hotspots around. Then I box them up and will pay for the "real" location assertion when it is installed. Better safe than sorry. It would be great if the fees were reduced, but at the same time, 10 bucks isn't going the break the bank.

John Mac 11/23/2022 7:13 PM
On average, 1,000,000 DC (current reassertion fee) takes a month's worth of mining. There are many setups that it would cost them a multiple of months' worth of mining. That's a lot. Furthermore, this HIP only pertains to those that meet the antigaming criteria. Which, based on Groot's data (ty Groot), this HIP may only apply to around 13% of all reassertions. For antigaming criteria details see: https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1001546633554710650/1006534946569060483 (edited)

John Mac 12/04/2022 11:20 AM
In addition to the gaming/abuse concerns, what happens after 3 months? We return to the 1000000 DC assertion fee permanently? The core goals of this HIP is to reduce the burden on those that want to expand the network (i.e. provide better coverage by relocating their hs into less densely populated locations) and to those new people joining the network (i.e. purchase second hand hs and need to reassert their locations accordingly, new people making human errors while asserting their hs, exc.) What happens to all the people that this HIP intends to help after 3 months? (edited)
John Mac
I understand, my issue is that I cannot bring myself in good conscious to implement stage 1 without any antigaming rules. I'd rather this HIP be archived, than allow it to cause any harm to the network.
waveform 12/04/2022 11:24 AM
After the HIP70 transition with off chain PoC we get hotspots beaconing more times a day than many do in a month, and all witnessing data is stored not just a random 14 of the possible dozens/hundreds in some cases. This massive amount of new data compared to the data available now plugged into the new AI anti gaming effort will allow for the very easy identification of gaming cheatnets and individual hotspots wrongly asserted. We really want a more accurate dataset of genuine placement, to make this identification easier, so lets give everyone the opportunity to be honourable and accurately place at a lower cost. Knowing that more accurate placements of real hotspots allows easier identification of spoofed locations with the new massive dataset.
2
1
waveform
After the HIP70 transition with off chain PoC we get hotspots beaconing more times a day than many do in a month, and all witnessing data is stored not just a random 14 of the possible dozens/hundreds in some cases. This massive amount of new data compared to the data available now plugged into the new AI anti gaming effort will allow for the very easy identification of gaming cheatnets and individual hotspots wrongly asserted. We really want a more accurate dataset of genuine placement, to make this identification easier, so lets give everyone the opportunity to be honourable and accurately place at a lower cost. Knowing that more accurate placements of real hotspots allows easier identification of spoofed locations with the new massive dataset.
John Mac 12/04/2022 11:27 AM
Ok, so I believe you are saying that post HIP 70 there will be methods for identifying and stopping gaming, and you would allow abuse intentionally to identify said abuse. If I'm understanding you correctly, then that's something I'd be completely ok with. However, the following questions remain. - What happens after 3 months? - Will the reassertion fee remain 1,000,000 DC permanently? - Do we implement the mathematical equation logic? If not, will we ever apply an alternative dynamic factorial? (edited)
John Mac
Ok, so I believe you are saying that post HIP 70 there will be methods for identifying and stopping gaming, and you would allow abuse intentionally to identify said abuse. If I'm understanding you correctly, then that's something I'd be completely ok with. However, the following questions remain. - What happens after 3 months? - Will the reassertion fee remain 1,000,000 DC permanently? - Do we implement the mathematical equation logic? If not, will we ever apply an alternative dynamic factorial? (edited)
waveform 12/04/2022 11:59 AM
If you remember previous messages the difficultly in applying logic to a variable fee was that the current way of requesting an assert is that the (1) hotspot management app sends a location request and a fee, the (2) blockchain checks this against the minimum fee for an assert for the type of gateway (Goto https://helium.plus/chain-vars and search for location) and if the fee paid is equal or higher and the lat/long are valid then it processes the assert or fails the transaction. For any logic and variable fees to work the HIP needs vendor apps and the blockchain to be re-written and do more of an enquire communication than send and get a pass/fail in return. And I doubt there is the time to work on this till Q2 or probably Q3 with all the other work going on. So my thought now was. Give everyone a chance to reassert where they really are with a reduced cost location assert. PoC should be more stable with the more predictable income the more accurately located you are. This will provide more accurate data to invalidate the really false and fake data from the cheatnets. How is it done? Change the chain vars above to a lower figure, and the end of 3 months change them back. That could be HIP69 part A, and Part B (what you have now) is a separate voteable part The variable cost of assertion logic part of this hip will be needed if hotspots with HIP72 concentrators want a cheap location assert because they can be trusted., unless they get their own chainvar.
waveform
If you remember previous messages the difficultly in applying logic to a variable fee was that the current way of requesting an assert is that the (1) hotspot management app sends a location request and a fee, the (2) blockchain checks this against the minimum fee for an assert for the type of gateway (Goto https://helium.plus/chain-vars and search for location) and if the fee paid is equal or higher and the lat/long are valid then it processes the assert or fails the transaction. For any logic and variable fees to work the HIP needs vendor apps and the blockchain to be re-written and do more of an enquire communication than send and get a pass/fail in return. And I doubt there is the time to work on this till Q2 or probably Q3 with all the other work going on. So my thought now was. Give everyone a chance to reassert where they really are with a reduced cost location assert. PoC should be more stable with the more predictable income the more accurately located you are. This will provide more accurate data to invalidate the really false and fake data from the cheatnets. How is it done? Change the chain vars above to a lower figure, and the end of 3 months change them back. That could be HIP69 part A, and Part B (what you have now) is a separate voteable part The variable cost of assertion logic part of this hip will be needed if hotspots with HIP72 concentrators want a cheap location assert because they can be trusted., unless they get their own chainvar.
John Mac 12/04/2022 2:05 PM

Of course, if we ever need to tweak the mathematical equations, logic, rules/criteria, exc. post HIP 70, then we may do so at that time. (edited)
John Mac 12/04/2022 3:44 PM
@waveform Why not split the vote into two as follows: 1) Stage/phase 1 will be an HNT vote to cut the assertion fees in half for the first three months post HIP 70 to correct their hotspots locations. Since everyone will be warned that, if they do not correct their hotspots to their actual location, then they will be caught for spoofing/cheating and blacklisted. The Foundation/Nova will also use the data derived from this for future antigaming/antispoofing proofing. 2) Stage/phase 2 will be a veIOT vote, to determine whether or not there should be a permanent or ongoing dynamic level mathematical equation, determining the ongoing reassertion fees. (Allowed, based on whatever proper antigaming eligibility/criteria methods we determine at that time.)
1

Since everyone will be warned that, if they do not correct their hotspots to their actual location, then they will be caught for spoofing/cheating and blacklisted. The Foundation/Nova will also use the data derived from this for future antigaming/antispoofing proofing. 2) Stage/phase 2 will be a veIOT vote, to determine whether or not there should be a permanent or ongoing dynamic level mathematical equation, determining the ongoing reassertion fees. That is the exact plan (edited)

valerie 12/16/2022 11:55 AM

we can take that then
John Mac 12/16/2022 11:57 AM
Here are the changes: This HIP will be voted on as follows: 1) Stage/phase 1 will be an HNT vote to cut the assertion fees in half for the first three months post HIP 70 to correct their hotspots locations, without any antigaming code. Since everyone will be warned that, if they do not correct their hotspots to their actual location, then they will be caught for spoofing/cheating and blacklisted. (This HIP itself will NOT blacklist hotspots.) The Foundation/Nova will also use the data derived from this for future antigaming/antispoofing proofing. After three months, the assertion fee will be reverted. If the vote is approved by the community, then this stage will be implemented via a simple chain variable. Therefore, no code is necessary for this stage. 2) Stage/phase 2 will be a veIOT vote, to determine whether or not there should be a permanent or ongoing dynamic level mathematical equation, determining the ongoing reassertion fees. (Allowed, based on whatever proper antigaming eligibility/criteria methods the Foundation determines appropriate at that time.) This stage requires a veIOT voting system, as well as antigaming and the dynamic level mathematical code. Additionally, it will help test the new veIOT voting system, and helps keep IOT in the treasury, which is beneficial for every IOT hotspot owner. Please note that this HIP does not impact 5G CBRS gateways & radios. (edited)
1
waveform pinned a message to this channel. 12/16/2022 12:45 PM

waveform 12/22/2022 4:26 AM

mhgdn 12/30/2022 5:33 AM
i think many people don't want re assert their hotspots correctly because of cost $/HNT. Asserted hotspost year ago in 'new hex' , earnigs was great, year ago we didn't have any crowdspot or hunting time to ban hs wrong asserted, nobody cared for wrong asserted hotspot year ago because everyone earn many HNT/$, Now HNT price is dropped so people trying to ban hs within your city to earn more hnt - more banned good located hs in city - more HNT income for bad placed hs in city in futere - this is logic for now. Year ago we had 'invalids' and that's it. After reduce price for re assert i think many people will re assert hotspots to place where they are - just because it is hunting time for now. If this hip pass it will be not fair for people that they have submission with wrong asserted hotspot, Make hip, reduce price, delete all submission with wrong asserted hotspots, (not clusters, etc. ) then: '' Since everyone will be warned that, if they do not correct their hotspots to their actual location, then they will be caught for spoofing/cheating and blacklisted. '' It will be fair for everyone. (edited)

John Mac 12/30/2022 6:39 AM
Hi, (in stage 1) this HIP will apply to ALL location assertions. Everyone will have three months to assert their hotspots to their correct or new locations at a 50% assertion fee rate (if desired or necessary.) It is fair for all, and is all inclusive. Side note, you are not required to reassert your hotspots. If your hotspots are already asserted to their correct locations, then there is no need (nor requirement) to reassert your hotspots locations. (edited)

John Mac 12/30/2022 6:43 AM
The antigaming rules (which will only apply to stage 2 not stage 1) are merely to help prevent people from taking advantage of this HIP's reassertion fee reductions, by limiting which assertions are eligible for the reassertion fee reduction. This HIP will not blacklist anyone, and will not detect (nor prevent) gaming/spoofing of the network. As is the title, this HIP is merely an assertion fee reduction. (edited)
John Mac
Hi, (in stage 1) this HIP will apply to ALL location assertions. Everyone will have three months to assert their hotspots to their correct or new locations at a 50% assertion fee rate (if desired or necessary.) It is fair for all, and is all inclusive. Side note, you are not required to reassert your hotspots. If your hotspots are already asserted to their correct locations, then there is no need (nor requirement) to reassert your hotspots locations. (edited)

John Mac 12/30/2022 7:26 AM
When I said that, 'since everyone will be warned that (if their hotspots aren't asserted to the correct locations and) if they don't correct their hotspots locations then (eventually) they will be caught and blacklisted,' I was explaining why we are offering an assertion fee discount to all assertions (with no restrictions whatsoever) during stage 1. Not because this HIP will blacklist them. The reasons why/how eventually they will be caught and blacklisted (which does not pertian to this HIP), is due to the secure concentrators, oracle capabilities, and future cheating/spoofing detection code (NOT this HIP). (edited)

John Mac 12/30/2022 7:59 AM
You are quoting me out of context, I'm talking about from that point moving forward, not retroactively/historically. Additionally, I'm referring to hotspots potentially being added to the deny list, not hotspots being removed from the deny list. If a hotspot is on the deny list, then it will stay on the deny list, regardless of whether or not they correct the location. To reiterate, this HIP will not add nor remove hotspots to/from the deny list, it is merely an assertion fee reduction. (edited)

John Mac 12/30/2022 8:30 AM

John Mac
You are quoting me out of context, I'm talking about from that point moving forward, not retroactively/historically. To reiterate, this HIP will not add nor remove hotspots to/from the deny list, it is merely an assertion fee reduction. (edited)

waveform 12/30/2022 10:35 AM
This HIP has zero direct relationship with denylist removals , the HIP is about the price paid for a location assert. If you think this HIP is about denylist removals then yes it wont make sense because you dont understand it. Incorrectly asserting the location is one of the bits of data that when viewed with the other data can get a hotspot on the denylist. Once its on the denylist, being correctly asserted is one of the bits of data that when viewed with the other data can get a hotspot off the denylist.
2
2

valerie pinned a message to this channel. 01/04/2023 7:28 AM
Siegfried 01/04/2023 7:49 AM
Just two minor details (that won't necessarily mean the HIP is not ready for voting): 1.
The average daily mining reward per hotspot is currently equal to around 50,000 DC; and it costs 1,000,000 DC to reassert a hotspot's location.
As the HIP initially proposed in summer when HNT price was a few times higher, so atm (using HNT price of 1,67 USD and average earnings of roughly 0,111 HNT) we are more like in the range of 18500 DC per day. Maybe want to adjust that roughly, so when the voting comes up people who read the HIP for the first time won't be confused. 2.
This HIP only applies to those who are REasserting their hotspots to a distance equal to or greater than 10km (away from the original location point that is being changed). As a direct result, this HIP will not help those trying to increase their TS scales.
The last sentence is not fully correct. Of course we do hope, that people try to increase their transmit scale by moving a hotspot far away to an empty or less crowded hex. The idea is, that the HIP will not help those trying to increase their TS scales by just moving their hotspot a few metres over the closest hex border and thus not improving overcrowding in the area of their location before moving. (edited)
07:52
I suggest to amend the quoted part by "by moving their hotspots only a few metres over the closest hex border." And maybe to better understand it: "Moving a hotspot only a few metres will not significantly decrease overcrowding."
07:53
Both aren't make or break improvement suggestions, but will help understand the HIP better in two places. And sorry, I am not Github literate enough to create a pull request for these suggestions. (edited)
07:57
@valerie just a quick notif before the triage stream

Anthonyra 01/04/2023 9:33 AM
The assert location cost was there to prevent blockchain spam and bloat. To also add skin to prevent gaming of PoC. It may not even be necessary with the move to Solana. For one all hotspots will beacon at intervals, and also being an NFT the blockchain won‚Äôt bloat on the changing of its metadata.. (to an extent depending on implementation of course). The question stands, would a simple chain var suffice and than it will be removed anyways?
Siegfried
Just two minor details (that won't necessarily mean the HIP is not ready for voting): 1.
The average daily mining reward per hotspot is currently equal to around 50,000 DC; and it costs 1,000,000 DC to reassert a hotspot's location.
As the HIP initially proposed in summer when HNT price was a few times higher, so atm (using HNT price of 1,67 USD and average earnings of roughly 0,111 HNT) we are more like in the range of 18500 DC per day. Maybe want to adjust that roughly, so when the voting comes up people who read the HIP for the first time won't be confused. 2.
This HIP only applies to those who are REasserting their hotspots to a distance equal to or greater than 10km (away from the original location point that is being changed). As a direct result, this HIP will not help those trying to increase their TS scales.
The last sentence is not fully correct. Of course we do hope, that people try to increase their transmit scale by moving a hotspot far away to an empty or less crowded hex. The idea is, that the HIP will not help those trying to increase their TS scales by just moving their hotspot a few metres over the closest hex border and thus not improving overcrowding in the area of their location before moving. (edited)
John Mac 01/04/2023 10:28 AM
Hi Siegfried, hope that you are feeling a lot better than the last time that we spoke. 1) Of course, I agree that the average earnings now is even lower than when I first wrote this HIP. However, that is all the more reason for the necessity of this HIP. 2) I'm not against changing my verbiage to match more of yours. However, this is merely a matter of verbiage, and (as you said) both of these suggestions have no effect on the overall HIP nor its implementation. As always, I appreciate your input, and I will make your suggested changes (at some point in the immediate future when possible.) (edited)

John Mac 01/04/2023 10:33 AM
Your first view sentences imply that you may not comprehend this HIP entirely. Since, both stages of this HIP are capable of being implemented both prior to and post the transition. The reason why stage 2 is waiting until after the transition, is since the necessary code and functionality will be a lot easier with oracles. Finally, DC is being burned still, and for all we know the reduction will end up causing more DC to be burned than prior to this HIP's assertion fee reduction- since there may end up being a lot more reassertions, resulting in more DC burned even with the assertion fee reduction. (edited)
Anthonyra
The assert location cost was there to prevent blockchain spam and bloat. To also add skin to prevent gaming of PoC. It may not even be necessary with the move to Solana. For one all hotspots will beacon at intervals, and also being an NFT the blockchain won‚Äôt bloat on the changing of its metadata.. (to an extent depending on implementation of course). The question stands, would a simple chain var suffice and than it will be removed anyways?

I'd personally rather not see anything that incentivizes gamers further, even if it hampers efforts on legit actors for now.
EdB-charlietango

John Mac 01/04/2023 10:44 AM
This is exactly why we changed stage 1 to be without any antigaming code, since without any antigaming code, it is extremely feasible via a simple chain variable. Additionally, due to the price of HNT (and retroactively the asserion cost,) upcoming secure concentrators, as well as new/future antigaming code, we are giving everyone a last chance to reassert their hotspots correctly at a discounted rate. (As we already explained https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1001546633554710650/1053400563947147355) (edited)
Discord - A New Way to Chat with Friends & Communities
Discord is the easiest way to communicate over voice, video, and text. Chat, hang out, and stay close with your friends and communities.
EdB-charlietango 01/04/2023 10:47 AM
All of my former hosts really haven't moved their hotspots so this wouldn't help them at all. I've reached out to my contact at Emrit to get their opinion on the utility of a reduced fee for a fleet company.
EdB-charlietango

@groot i hear you but i think it sets the wrong precedent about changing fees in the network, especially for reasons that are unclear. the motivation of this hip was to help honest hotspot owners reassert in lower density/saturated areas. that assumes so much about the behavior of either commercial or individual hotspot owners. Im not even sure there is some massive group in the network that desperately wants to reassert to less saturated areas. how often is it that folks are moving to rural areas? and if the problem is we want to incentivize the deployment of hotspots to lower saturated areas, theres some way better overarching strategy we should be creating. your not just gonna get your average user to move to a rural or less saturated area just because the fee for their existing hotspot is low.

EdB-charlietango 01/04/2023 1:37 PM
IIP? IOTIP? veIOTIP?
1
groot
Seems like semantics, but sure, if it helps to give stage 2 a different number I‚Äôm sure @John Mac can be persuaded to agree.
EdB-charlietango 01/04/2023 1:45 PM
It's not semantics. It's a technique in large, scaling orgs regarding story splitting which enhances both the speed of getting the HIP/story through and also the quality of the HIP/story. So if I come off as an ass, while that can and should be improved, I'm quite based in the advice I'm giving. And there are others here as well who are trying to help.

waveform 01/04/2023 1:56 PM
Ed, after the understanding that this originally more complicated HIP would take a lot of work in the vendor apps and blockchain which would be unlikely till Q3 or beyond I made some suggestions to John to make it initially simple based on his original idea of reducing reassert fees so the HIP could either die or progress. See my comments from here https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1001546633554710650/1048552658883051530
groot

John Mac 01/04/2023 1:57 PM
I'm more than happy to rewrite or write a second HIP for stage 2.
13:59
Which would need to wait until after the three months is up and we know exactly which of the antigaming criteria methods is still valid and which needs to be removed/changed/added
cokes 01/04/2023 1:59 PM
from an implementation perspective, this is what would need to happen for stage 2 to work, if passed as written: app does all the checks on assert location in the app, let the user select the new asserted location. the app will have to decide if it is less than, or more than 10km based on lat/long on chain or in metadata of NFT (post-L1 transition). if more than 10km, store in memory. do the next check. if less than 10km, $10 assert fee applies. check if new lat/long's h3 has less than 3 hotspots. if true, continue to next check. if more, $10 assert fee applies. check if the last "reduced assert" (and not $10 assert) was more than 525,000 blocks ago. if true, confirm $5 assert fee to user in app. if false, $10 fee applies. app bundles the assert_location transaction with the correct fee and submits to black wallet app for signing and submission. then Blockchain does the checks, just like transfer hotspot looks for most recent poc challenge for liveness check when an assert_location txn is submitted with a certain fee, the blockchain will have to check when the last time a Hotspot received a "reduced fee assert", assess the new lat/long is more than 10km away from old lat/long, AND decide if new lat/long's h3 hex has less than 3 hotspots at that time. It will then let the transaction through or let it fail. of course, the ux of the blockchain checking will be poor as users will not know why the transaction failed without the app checks. app checks basically mean a huge maker app undertaking along with blockchain updates
1
waveform
Ed, after the understanding that this originally more complicated HIP would take a lot of work in the vendor apps and blockchain which would be unlikely till Q3 or beyond I made some suggestions to John to make it initially simple based on his original idea of reducing reassert fees so the HIP could either die or progress. See my comments from here https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1001546633554710650/1048552658883051530

cokes
from an implementation perspective, this is what would need to happen for stage 2 to work, if passed as written: app does all the checks on assert location in the app, let the user select the new asserted location. the app will have to decide if it is less than, or more than 10km based on lat/long on chain or in metadata of NFT (post-L1 transition). if more than 10km, store in memory. do the next check. if less than 10km, $10 assert fee applies. check if new lat/long's h3 has less than 3 hotspots. if true, continue to next check. if more, $10 assert fee applies. check if the last "reduced assert" (and not $10 assert) was more than 525,000 blocks ago. if true, confirm $5 assert fee to user in app. if false, $10 fee applies. app bundles the assert_location transaction with the correct fee and submits to black wallet app for signing and submission. then Blockchain does the checks, just like transfer hotspot looks for most recent poc challenge for liveness check when an assert_location txn is submitted with a certain fee, the blockchain will have to check when the last time a Hotspot received a "reduced fee assert", assess the new lat/long is more than 10km away from old lat/long, AND decide if new lat/long's h3 hex has less than 3 hotspots at that time. It will then let the transaction through or let it fail. of course, the ux of the blockchain checking will be poor as users will not know why the transaction failed without the app checks. app checks basically mean a huge maker app undertaking along with blockchain updates
John Mac 01/04/2023 2:02 PM
This is fantastic data, thank you very much Cokes. Stage 2 will need to be entirely rewritten (or made into an entire new HIP.) This is due to the various new/future antigaming code (being created by starwatcher and others,) secure concentrators, and of course oracle capabilities/functionality that may make some/most of the antigaming criteria methods outlined in stage 2 obsolete.
cokes
from an implementation perspective, this is what would need to happen for stage 2 to work, if passed as written: app does all the checks on assert location in the app, let the user select the new asserted location. the app will have to decide if it is less than, or more than 10km based on lat/long on chain or in metadata of NFT (post-L1 transition). if more than 10km, store in memory. do the next check. if less than 10km, $10 assert fee applies. check if new lat/long's h3 has less than 3 hotspots. if true, continue to next check. if more, $10 assert fee applies. check if the last "reduced assert" (and not $10 assert) was more than 525,000 blocks ago. if true, confirm $5 assert fee to user in app. if false, $10 fee applies. app bundles the assert_location transaction with the correct fee and submits to black wallet app for signing and submission. then Blockchain does the checks, just like transfer hotspot looks for most recent poc challenge for liveness check when an assert_location txn is submitted with a certain fee, the blockchain will have to check when the last time a Hotspot received a "reduced fee assert", assess the new lat/long is more than 10km away from old lat/long, AND decide if new lat/long's h3 hex has less than 3 hotspots at that time. It will then let the transaction through or let it fail. of course, the ux of the blockchain checking will be poor as users will not know why the transaction failed without the app checks. app checks basically mean a huge maker app undertaking along with blockchain updates

waveform 01/04/2023 2:05 PM
No, vendor apps would need to change assert request to be $5, they could still request $10 and it would pass. So a "fail" to implement would still go thru at the higher price. 3 months later there is another issue that a $5 request would fail the return to the higher $10 fee. So they need a change then too
John Mac
Right now, the only matter in play is stage 1. Please confirm that simply cutting all assertion fees in half can be accomplished via chain vars.
cokes 01/04/2023 2:05 PM
not as simple as a chain var. if initial assert is to remain at $10. there is only 1 chain var that handles the assert cost and it doesn't differentiate between first assert and subsequent asserts. https://hp.hn/cv/#staking_fee_txn_assert_location_v1

EdB-charlietango 01/04/2023 2:06 PM
Oh crud. That has increased complexities for situations like Syncrobit, et al. Is there any danger for a vendor app to request at an increased factor of assert fee?
cokes
have you determined the economic impact of a 50% reduction as it applies to the burn and mint equilibrium?
John Mac 01/04/2023 2:08 PM
Yes, we have determined that it is impossible to accurately predict whether or not this (cutting all assertion fee in half for three months) will have a positive or negative impact on the network. This is since there may end up being more DC burnt (as a direct result of this HIP stage 1) due to many more assertions occurring.

waveform 01/04/2023 2:27 PM
On the "this will help gamers" subject these were my thinkings.... Most gamers assert wrongly and should now be caught by the new Denylist Algorhythm, even if fee is reduced they should still get caught. What we do need to spot these are that more honest hotspots have their location asserted more accurately, to show up the cheaters more easily and quicker. How do we get more accurate location asserts ..... a promotion for reduction in location fees is one option.
3

John Mac 01/05/2023 6:21 AM
My apologies for the confusion. What we are voting on is only stage 1. Stage 1 is simply to cut all assertion fees in half, for three months, beginning immediately upon the migration to Solana. Nothing more, nothing less. In terms of code, none is necessary, since this may be accomplished via chain vars. I've completely rewritten the entire HIP on GitHub accordingly and submitted a pull request. All other factors of the HIP (including stage 2) are no longer relevant and will need to be rewritten in a new HIP. @cokes @valerie and @ all, my sincere apologies for the confusion. (edited)

groot 01/17/2023 11:38 AM
Is that even true? I thought we deducted last time that the hotspot apps using the helium js libraries get those variables from chain vars automatically. The only thing they would them possibly need to do is make the text field dynamic (e.g. $5 instead of $10)
groot
Is that even true? I thought we deducted last time that the hotspot apps using the helium js libraries get those variables from chain vars automatically. The only thing they would them possibly need to do is make the text field dynamic (e.g. $5 instead of $10)
waveform 01/17/2023 11:44 AM
Apparently not. And the assert is not an "at least $5" transaction but has to be exact. So if they don't change from $10 to $5 their asserts fail rather than go thru at the higher price. The Helium app used to get the variable from an API call but after the API problems it was changed to a fixed value. Not sure about all the others. We really do need to avoid the "Solana migration is a disaster I cant onboard" messages in the first few days.

John Mac 01/19/2023 5:25 AM

waveform

waveform 01/19/2023 5:26 AM
Reporting back on my checks. The vendor apps are probably all based on the example "Maker Starter App" and background Software Development Kit referenced at https://docs.helium.com/mine-hnt/maker-apps/ The starter app does retrieve the location assert value from a remote location (not an API to stop assertions hanging when the API is sluggish) see https://discordapp.com/channels/404106811252408320/730245373037379647/1065007225686466580 This value is regularly obtained from the Helium L1 API, and in the future on Solana it will be either retrieved from a Helium Oracle on Solana or a remote location that provides access to "chainvars" similar to this site now https://hp.hn/cv/#staking_fee_txn_assert_location_light_gateway_v1
waveform
Reporting back on my checks. The vendor apps are probably all based on the example "Maker Starter App" and background Software Development Kit referenced at https://docs.helium.com/mine-hnt/maker-apps/ The starter app does retrieve the location assert value from a remote location (not an API to stop assertions hanging when the API is sluggish) see https://discordapp.com/channels/404106811252408320/730245373037379647/1065007225686466580 This value is regularly obtained from the Helium L1 API, and in the future on Solana it will be either retrieved from a Helium Oracle on Solana or a remote location that provides access to "chainvars" similar to this site now https://hp.hn/cv/#staking_fee_txn_assert_location_light_gateway_v1

Reporting back on my checks. The vendor apps are probably all based on the example "Maker Starter App" and background Software Development Kit referenced at https://docs.helium.com/mine-hnt/maker-apps/ The starter app does retrieve the location assert value from a remote location (not an API to stop assertions hanging when the API is sluggish) see https://discordapp.com/channels/404106811252408320/730245373037379647/1065007225686466580 This value is regularly obtained from the Helium L1 API, and in the future on Solana it will be either retrieved from a Helium Oracle on Solana or a remote location that provides access to "chainvars" similar to this site now https://hp.hn/cv/#staking_fee_txn_assert_location_light_gateway_v1

John Mac 01/24/2023 6:06 AM
Quick update. Due to the time sensitive urgency of HIP 75, this HIP will be voted on after HIP 75. Aiming for voting (on this HIP [69]) next week, but obviously the decisions aren't mine to make. Thank you to all for your continued support P.S. Upon the transition to Solana and the completion of this HIP, I'll be rewriting a new HIP (for what was stage/phase 2 of the original HIP 69,) in order for there to be a permanent ongoing dynamic level mathematical equation logic- that determines the future assertion fees pricing. However, that HIP may need to be voted on via the new veIOT voting system, and may need to wait for the completion of the new veIOT voting system. (edited)
2
John Mac
Quick update. Due to the time sensitive urgency of HIP 75, this HIP will be voted on after HIP 75. Aiming for voting (on this HIP [69]) next week, but obviously the decisions aren't mine to make. Thank you to all for your continued support P.S. Upon the transition to Solana and the completion of this HIP, I'll be rewriting a new HIP (for what was stage/phase 2 of the original HIP 69,) in order for there to be a permanent ongoing dynamic level mathematical equation logic- that determines the future assertion fees pricing. However, that HIP may need to be voted on via the new veIOT voting system, and may need to wait for the completion of the new veIOT voting system. (edited)

2
waveform 02/01/2023 3:29 PM
Anyone installing a new hotspot in the first 3 months of the solana blockchain will not benefit from the $5 reduction. The hotspot maker will. This should encourage makers to ensure the maker app makes the right request of $5 not $10 for the first location assertion during this period. This was why John was asked to contact them and ensure they were onboard with the idea. Anyone reasserting an existing hotspot in the first 3 months of the solana blockchain will pay the reduced fee, this is to encourage correctly reasserting ones that are not asserted in the matching real location and to relocate ones that are not in great locations.
2

EdB-charlietango 02/01/2023 4:33 PM
My thought FOR HIP69: Any legit moving around or fine-tuning of PoC is a good thing.
16:34
My thought AGAINST HIP69: Maximize the amount of work NOT done (agile principle) - still dependent on makers to rebuild app and deploy it. It's only for 3 months and therefore not consequential and no verifiable data that it will work as intended. (in re-reading this, I meant that potential delays in makers making updates could eat into that 3 months of time. Also, that it would be good to have some data beforehand.) (edited)
16:35
I welcome any thoughts for/against my thinking. I'm truly open-minded on this one.

John Mac 02/01/2023 5:23 PM
Not everything is ground braking and not everything solves problems. This HIP merely aims to help ease the burden on those looking to expand the network, those who purchased second hotspots and need to reassert their hotspots locations, those who accidentally asserted their hotspots locations inaccurately, vendors first assertion fees, and provide helpful data to catch spoofers, as well as provide helpful data towards the follow up HIP (that was stage 2 of this HIP,) exc. (edited)

John Mac 02/02/2023 6:21 AM
This HIP will reduce the location assertion fee from 1,000,000 DC ($10) to 500,000 DC ($5) for three months upon the migration to Solana
06:21
(Of course, if approved by community vote.*)

John Mac 02/02/2023 6:29 AM
Please have a read, this should clear it up. https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0069-reassertion-fee-reduction.md
HIP/0069-reassertion-fee-reduction.md at main · helium/HIP
Helium Improvement Proposals. Contribute to helium/HIP development by creating an account on GitHub.
MondoARG 02/02/2023 6:30 AM
I writing we call it the Executive Summary. Because busy people need the TLDR up front. Whenever I have to send a mass email, I assume I have lost half of my audience by the 3rd sentence.
MondoARG
I writing we call it the Executive Summary. Because busy people need the TLDR up front. Whenever I have to send a mass email, I assume I have lost half of my audience by the 3rd sentence.
John Mac 02/02/2023 6:31 AM
TLDR executive summary: https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1001546633554710650/1070514702200881192
MondoARG 02/02/2023 6:32 AM
I'm straight now. The Summary has the schedule. It was just not the first thing that populated to the feed.
1
John Mac 02/02/2023 6:33 AM
Summary: The average daily mining reward per hotspot is currently equal to around 18,500 DC; and it costs 1,000,000 DC to reassert a hotspot's location. As a result, it would take more than a month for the average hotspot to earn enough DC to pay for one location assertion. Therefore, if we are trying to expand the network and want hotspots in saturated areas to move into less saturated areas, want to ease the burden on new people joining the network, and ease the burden on people making human errors, the current reassertion fee is not viable and needs to be reduced. Please note that it is likely the hotspots which are earning below average income, are the ones that would want to change locations most, so the current assertion costs would be greater than 30 days average earnings for those hotspots. In order to help ease the burden on those looking to expand the network, ease the burden on those that (accidentally) asserted their hotspots locations inaccurately, new people joining who purchased secondhand hotspots, exc. I'm proposing that the reassertion price be reduced from 1,000,000 DC to half (which is 500,000 DC) for 3 (three) months post HIP-70's transition to Solana. (edited)
MondoARG 02/02/2023 6:37 AM

Just one? Gotta love the democracy of our voting system, reminds me of the US presidential election. By popular (individual total) vote, as of this moment, over 8X more voted for. Yet, due to the HNT weighted vote factorial, all it took was one vote to swing the vote by nearly 30% against. (edited)

John Mac 02/06/2023 5:53 AM
Out of the 386 votes since that first snapshot (that was at 66.6% for), 32 voted againt and 354 voted for, resulting in a 1.37% increase in total/HNT weighted for this HIP. Individual votes may have never counted more than now.

John Mac 02/06/2023 2:59 PM
In the original HIP 69, we had various antigaming rules, to prevent gamers from taking advantage of cheaper reassertion fees. This was removed, out of practicality that the work would entail, one of the reasons why we made it for only three months, and will be required in the follow-up HIP. https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/1001546633554710650/1006534946569060483 (edited)
15:01
The follow-up HIP will have the antigaming rules (that are still relevant at that time) in addition to the dynamic level mathematical equation which determines the permanent ongoing reassertion fees (depending on the average earnings per hotspot, the oracle value of HNT, exc.)
1

Cari 02/07/2023 2:22 AM
@John Mac If a discount or free location change is made for those who mark a fake location for once or only decide to be an honest user after being in a fake location, don't you think it will significantly reduce the number of fake location devices? Or is it an opportunity for players
Cari
@John Mac If a discount or free location change is made for those who mark a fake location for once or only decide to be an honest user after being in a fake location, don't you think it will significantly reduce the number of fake location devices? Or is it an opportunity for players
waveform 02/07/2023 2:28 AM
People with false locations asserted will have a 3 month period during which reasserting correctly will be $5 not $10 to encourage them. People wanting to falsely assert will also get this $5 reduction, but the denylist algorithms are there catching people who do this. The only "free" location change is the first, and that is paid by the hotspot maker, who will pay $5 not $10.
3
waveform
People with false locations asserted will have a 3 month period during which reasserting correctly will be $5 not $10 to encourage them. People wanting to falsely assert will also get this $5 reduction, but the denylist algorithms are there catching people who do this. The only "free" location change is the first, and that is paid by the hotspot maker, who will pay $5 not $10.

groot

I(TrY)Fix(IT) 02/09/2023 2:56 AM
bicuase of this i see actualy important to define it.
waveform 02/09/2023 3:11 AM
In reality you are assigned to the centre of a res12 hex which is 17m across flats. So 8.5-17m is true flexi distance where it doesnt matter. Obviously we recognise that people want to missassert from the exact location because of security, safety, prevent theft etc. But I dont think there is ever going to be a ... here is what you are allowed to misassert by distance number. As being in an offgrid placement in a rural location 100m might not be enough for security, but is undetectable if who you witness is 10km away. But 100m out in a city location when there are dozens of hotspots around you and maybe some closer would really show up as wildly misasserted.
2
2
John Mac 02/09/2023 5:32 AM
Just feel the need to express this. When I submitted the first PR for this HIP around half a year ago, two people DMed me saying that "only the Foundation's/Nova's HIP's go to vote and are implemented" and that I'm "wasting my time." They were clearly wrong, and this HIP is proof of that; as well as, proof that if you are willing to do the work, anyone can write a HIP that can get voted on and implemented. Additionally, every vote does count, especially when more people are actually voting. Looking forward to the Solana migration, (for the implementation of this HIP, all that Solana will bring to the table, and) when the cost of voting will be relatively free. (edited)
4
2
3
2
waveform
In reality you are assigned to the centre of a res12 hex which is 17m across flats. So 8.5-17m is true flexi distance where it doesnt matter. Obviously we recognise that people want to missassert from the exact location because of security, safety, prevent theft etc. But I dont think there is ever going to be a ... here is what you are allowed to misassert by distance number. As being in an offgrid placement in a rural location 100m might not be enough for security, but is undetectable if who you witness is 10km away. But 100m out in a city location when there are dozens of hotspots around you and maybe some closer would really show up as wildly misasserted.
gtelnet 02/09/2023 10:01 AM
Something that would be great for legitimate hotspot operators would be a "warning list" of hotspots that fall within the parameters of "wildly misasserted", which the hotspots go to for the three month duration of this HIP's fee reduction, before they are moved to the deny list. This would give honest "city" people the opportunity to fix their location, before they are moved to the deny list, which seems more difficult to get removed from. After the HIP expires, and as future location/distance rules potentially change via new HIPs, it would be nice to use this same "warning list" process permanently, but for a shorter period of time, i.e. 30 days, for newbies to be able to fix their location before it gets put on the deny list. Explorer could display the warning and companies like Hotspotty could easily show their customers if they are on the "warning list", the same way they currently do for the deny list. And very well said @John Mac.
1
10:04
That would also eliminate the need to ever provide the "here is what you are allowed to misassert by distance number", and would give the hotspot owner the ability to move it around until explorer removes the warning.
gtelnet

This would give honest "city" people the opportunity to fix their location, before they are moved to the deny list, which seems more difficult to get removed from. After the HIP expires, and as future location/distance rules potentially change via new HIPs, it would be nice to use this same "warning list" process permanently, but for a shorter period of time, i.e. 30 days, for newbies to be able to fix their location before it gets put on the deny list. Explorer could display the warning and companies like Hotspotty could easily show their customers if they are on the "warning list", the same way they currently do for the deny list. And very well said @John Mac.

John Mac 02/09/2023 10:28 AM
Your "warning list" idea is a good one IMO. However, I'm no software developer, and have no idea what kind and how much work this would entail. As it is, all hands have been on deck with off-chain PoC, and the upcoming migration to Solana. Appreciate your message(s) and support (edited)
gutentag
Oooor just assert directly in the first place if you think there is a concern? HIP-69 is an amazing opportunity to do just that. And reminder no one single factor will put a Hotspot on the denylist
gtelnet 02/09/2023 10:37 AM
Asserting directly goes against what @waveform wrote "Obviously we recognise that people want to missassert from the exact location because of security, safety, prevent theft etc." And while no one factor will put it on the deny list, it seems it would be a fair policy to let people know what factor(s) put them on the warning list, prior to being put on the deny list. At the end of the day, the hackers/gamers will forever continue playing leap frog with the developers, figuring out ways around the code that's written, and the regular folk who are just trying to obscure the hotspot from showing which house they live in could potentially get put on the deny list without warning. Just recently, Nova posted about an issue with the deny list submissions, where innocent people were put on it inadvertently. That will happen again, but could at least be mitigated by a 30 day grace period.
gtelnet

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/03/2023 3:07 PM
Nice recovery.
John Mac
Summary: The average daily mining reward per hotspot is currently equal to around 18,500 DC; and it costs 1,000,000 DC to reassert a hotspot's location. As a result, it would take more than a month for the average hotspot to earn enough DC to pay for one location assertion. Therefore, if we are trying to expand the network and want hotspots in saturated areas to move into less saturated areas, want to ease the burden on new people joining the network, and ease the burden on people making human errors, the current reassertion fee is not viable and needs to be reduced. Please note that it is likely the hotspots which are earning below average income, are the ones that would want to change locations most, so the current assertion costs would be greater than 30 days average earnings for those hotspots. In order to help ease the burden on those looking to expand the network, ease the burden on those that (accidentally) asserted their hotspots locations inaccurately, new people joining who purchased secondhand hotspots, exc. I'm proposing that the reassertion price be reduced from 1,000,000 DC to half (which is 500,000 DC) for 3 (three) months post HIP-70's transition to Solana. (edited)
Moxxie 03/04/2023 9:22 AM
soo its for the first 3 months of solana?, wouldnt it be better it it was for the first 2 times or smth
Moxxie
soo its for the first 3 months of solana?, wouldnt it be better it it was for the first 2 times or smth
John Mac 03/04/2023 9:26 AM
Yes, for the first three months after the Solona migration. This HIP is an experiment to see if I should write up another HIP (rewrite what was stage 2 of this HIP,) which includes a permanent ongoing dynamic level mathematical equation logic (that determines the reassertion fee based on the oracle value of HNT, average daily earnings per hotspot, exc.)
Moxxie 03/04/2023 10:25 AM
Okay thanks
Moxxie
Okay thanks
John Mac 03/04/2023 5:21 PM

shorai 03/09/2023 11:06 AM
Following from discussions o on crowdspot, there should be p provision for free reason within the bounds of the original assertion as given by GPS error. e.g. I asserted using the good given by my cellphone directly to the onboarding app. That co-ordinate is about 60m distant from the actual location as given on Google Earth. That location was adequate at the time. Crowdspot now want to penalize me by 3 weeks POC inn order to bring the hotspot to within 2m. Of its location. For some hotspots that's is impossible to find since GPS of sheet on times of war, and there are no landmarks close enough to act as reference points.
shorai

That location was adequate at the time. Crowdspot now want to penalize me by 3 weeks POC inn order to bring the hotspot to within 2m. Of its location. For some hotspots that's is impossible to find since GPS of sheet on times of war, and there are no landmarks close enough to act as reference points.
waveform 03/09/2023 11:14 AM
When you assert you should "snap" to the centre of the Resolution 12 sized hex you have the pin pointed at. These are 17m wide. So you could be out by 8-9m anyway. So there is no way 2m accuracy is required.
1
John Mac 03/09/2023 12:26 PM
(Additionally, this should be taken up in the appropriate #crowdspot channel.)
waveform
When you assert you should "snap" to the centre of the Resolution 12 sized hex you have the pin pointed at. These are 17m wide. So you could be out by 8-9m anyway. So there is no way 2m accuracy is required.

shorai 03/09/2023 9:43 PM
When you are on the field seeing up, you need to assert and the simplest is to accept the GPS figure which is ready by the asserting software. There should be no need to type on the co- ordinates. At the timer, the accuracy was sufficient since crowdspot did not exist and the requirement was simply to be within a much larger hex.. more, suddenly, the requirement is much more stringent and the consequences much greater. There should be a period of grace to p put the asserted location right without financial. Impact. I'm not talking 2km, I'm talking GPS error bounds
gutentag 03/09/2023 9:46 PM
- you dont type in coordinates, you drag your finger on the screen like any other mapping application. - the guidance of "assert your Hotspot as accurately as possible" has always been the case. - HIP-69 is that grace period to correct assertions.
shorai 03/10/2023 2:58 AM
Perhaps you have done this to often. When you do it for the first few times you don't remember the exact things you do.. I still think that the accuracy given by the GPS should be sufficient. There should them be clear instructions as to the accuracy requirements. This was not the case in May June last year when at least some off the recommendations were that it was ok to assert some distance away from accurate position due to privacy concerns. I will talking about within the same hex(I think this means level 7 or 8 as displayed on explorer), But definitely not the level 12 now being spoken off. With the change, there should be a free grace period to correct. And most definitely this should never have been the cause of a denial of service that affected the usefulness of the hotspot as was the case. They still should be a period of grace for a free correction within the bounds given by a GPS on the asserting cellphone which was within 1 metre of the hotspot at the time and the hard line attitude should have been adequately explained both to me as well as the menu tryouts and mods on both this forum as well as the manufacturer forums. This was not the case.
03:04
I take exception to what I see as a money grabbing exercise at the expense of legitimate hotspot owners, whilst do called gamers have been given free reign to deplete the resources for a long time. These controls are the domain of the foundation and Nova and are normally Bourn by the network operator as part of the security offering. I see this as negligence on their part. The fact that they do not seem prepared to find the correction of these security negligence further indicated to me a lack of accountability for network controls that should have been part of the base design.
shorai

If it's always been a res 12 and a GPS cannot keep that resolution, then there is something wrong, and at the very least the should be a warning that GPS is inadequate.
waveform 03/10/2023 3:44 AM
Im really not sure what your GPS resolution/accuracy question has to do with anything. There is no GPS in the hotspots (usually) and the phone you use to assert the location on a hotspot could be 1000s of miles away from the hotspot.
shorai 03/10/2023 3:50 AM
Could be, but wasn't. It was literally at the base of the 3m pole the antenna is mounted on. It was within 5m for a period of at least 0.5 hour before, yet gives a location about 40m distant. In my ignorance, I accepted the GPS reasons offered during the assertion and found out later that the position was incorrect. By that time, the cost to correct was$10. No the phone was connected via Bluetooth i.e. only a few metres away maximum. The cell phone display was unreadable to any degree of accuracy in the sunlight.
shorai

John Mac 03/15/2023 9:18 AM
For those that missed it, Waveform confirmed that Noah already changed the Solana chain var for the location assert fee that the maker apps pull for a location assert from 1M DC to 500K DC to match HIP-69's implementation. The only outstanding matter (regarding HIP-69's implementation) is that the text in the vendor apps may still reference $10 (not $5).
1
3
Carl-bot BOT 03/15/2023 9:18 AM
The Helium Hotspot App is being superceeded by the Helium Wallet App https://docs.helium.com/wallets/helium-wallet-app to manage Tokens and Identities and is needed for HNT/IOT/MOBILE access after the transition to the Solana blockchain. And also Hotspot Vendor's Apps will be required to manage Hotspots (diagnostics, asserting location, adding Hotspots, etc) https://docs.helium.com/mine-hnt/maker-apps/#known-maker-apps
Charles (nowisensors.com) 03/17/2023 7:23 AM
This is a tangential HIP but I figured this is a good channel to begin discussion. These days gateways are getting cheaper and cheaper, the new Seeed Gateway is only $99 with assertion fee and a location change included, which really means the gateway is $49 with $50 of Helium fees, meaning the fees are DOUBLING the cost of deployments. This is a clear demonstration to me why assertion fees are now too high. My goal is to write a HIP to decrease at the assertion fee to something more reasonable, i.e. $10/ gateway. Would love any feedback.
Charles (nowisensors.com)
This is a tangential HIP but I figured this is a good channel to begin discussion. These days gateways are getting cheaper and cheaper, the new Seeed Gateway is only $99 with assertion fee and a location change included, which really means the gateway is $49 with $50 of Helium fees, meaning the fees are DOUBLING the cost of deployments. This is a clear demonstration to me why assertion fees are now too high. My goal is to write a HIP to decrease at the assertion fee to something more reasonable, i.e. $10/ gateway. Would love any feedback.
Siegfried 03/17/2023 8:08 AM
For IOT, assertion fees traditionally had been at $10 per hotspot. With temporary reduction to $5. Sure you are talking about assertion fees, not onboarding fees (which are $40 atm). Or am I missing something here? (Btw, I am all for reducing onboarding and assertion fees as far as there are no convincing reasons to have them high/higher.)
1
Siegfried
For IOT, assertion fees traditionally had been at $10 per hotspot. With temporary reduction to $5. Sure you are talking about assertion fees, not onboarding fees (which are $40 atm). Or am I missing something here? (Btw, I am all for reducing onboarding and assertion fees as far as there are no convincing reasons to have them high/higher.)
Charles (nowisensors.com) 03/17/2023 8:10 AM
Yes I meant the $40 onboarding/assert hotspot fee
1
Charles (nowisensors.com)
Yes I meant the $40 onboarding/assert hotspot fee
Siegfried 03/17/2023 8:15 AM
A side thought: I wonder whether we shouldn't decrease the onboarding fee right away. Some time in the future, there will be a significant reward cuts for hotspots in overcrowded hexes. If new devices are incredibly cheap, we might put price pressure on used devices that could be moved (they already paid onboarding fees), thus leading to significantly more people maybe not selling them but throwing them away/not bothering reselling them. Thus increasing electronics waste. (edited)
Siegfried
A side thought: I wonder whether we shouldn't decrease the onboarding fee right away. Some time in the future, there will be a significant reward cuts for hotspots in overcrowded hexes. If new devices are incredibly cheap, we might put price pressure on used devices that could be moved (they already paid onboarding fees), thus leading to significantly more people maybe not selling them but throwing them away/not bothering reselling them. Thus increasing electronics waste. (edited)
Charles (nowisensors.com) 03/17/2023 8:25 AM
I can see this HIP moving through quickly, and I hope it does
John Mac 03/17/2023 9:53 AM
@Charles (nowisensors.com) @Siegfried Just to add to the conversation, this HIP was originally written back in July of last year, way before the halving and current light hotspots. Additionally, this HIP originally had two phases, with the second containing a permanent ongoing dynamic level mathematical equation logic. This was changed to the current HIP-69, for many reasons, mostly implementation practicality. Upon the completion of HIP-69, assuming successful, I intend on writing a new HIP. The bew HIP will contain what was stage 2 of this HIP, whatever antigaming rules that are still relevant at that time, and now I'll also consider implementing a reduced onboarding fee structure (due to your aforementioned light hotspots and other points.) That being said, reducing onboarding/assertion fees is not something that is easy to write off, due to the potential negative economic impact on the Network (which may result from reduced onboarding/location assertions fees/burning less HNT.) As intended, this HIP will also provide great data towards that end, and is merely a stepping stone if you will.
1
John Mac
@Charles (nowisensors.com) @Siegfried Just to add to the conversation, this HIP was originally written back in July of last year, way before the halving and current light hotspots. Additionally, this HIP originally had two phases, with the second containing a permanent ongoing dynamic level mathematical equation logic. This was changed to the current HIP-69, for many reasons, mostly implementation practicality. Upon the completion of HIP-69, assuming successful, I intend on writing a new HIP. The bew HIP will contain what was stage 2 of this HIP, whatever antigaming rules that are still relevant at that time, and now I'll also consider implementing a reduced onboarding fee structure (due to your aforementioned light hotspots and other points.) That being said, reducing onboarding/assertion fees is not something that is easy to write off, due to the potential negative economic impact on the Network (which may result from reduced onboarding/location assertions fees/burning less HNT.) As intended, this HIP will also provide great data towards that end, and is merely a stepping stone if you will.
Charles (nowisensors.com) 03/17/2023 9:57 AM
I think the only real reason to have an onboarding/location assertion fee is to prevent spamming and gaming. Relying on those fees to create economic value for the network is a blockade to the physical network growth which should be the real network driver. I think you probably agree there.
1

John Mac 04/21/2023 6:29 AM
@groot being that you're likely swamped with matters infinitely more important, only when you get a chance, (and feel like it too) please can you run those fantastic custom reports you created that detail the (location) assertions data for the last few months (4 max) so that we can make an accurate comparison pre/post the implementation of this HIP? waveform 04/25/2023 3:03 AM
Location update is still doable on the if you have a Helium OG hotspot. Otherwise you need to use the maker app or the hotspotty app if it supports it. The warning message probably says $10 but they will go thru at $5. If unsure just have $5-$9 worth of DC in the wallet. If its $5 it will go thru, if $10 it will fail ....
waveform
Location update is still doable on the if you have a Helium OG hotspot. Otherwise you need to use the maker app or the hotspotty app if it supports it. The warning message probably says $10 but they will go thru at $5. If unsure just have $5-$9 worth of DC in the wallet. If its $5 it will go thru, if $10 it will fail ....
